characters: STUDIO, LEEFOLT HOME, HILLY'S HOME, AND ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIBILEEN, black, 53, sits at a table in a small, green kitchen. She wears a yellow dress with black piping and grips a tattered spiral notebook. Although cracked, the window behind her is crystal clear. Three framed portraits hang on the wall above her: John F Kennedy, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and an UNKNOWN YOUNG BLACK MALE wearing thick glasses. Aibileen swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was...born in 1911...on Piedmont Plantation in Cherokee County. An UNSEEN WOMAN interviews Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Did you know as a girl, growing up, that one day you'd be a maid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. I did.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: And you knew that because?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma was a maid. My grandmother was a house slave.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Oh. The woman repeats Aibileen's answer slowly as she writes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: A...House...Slave. Uh-huh. Okay. Aibileen squeezes the notebook in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Now, did you ever dream of being something else? Aibileen gulps. She doesn't answer. The room is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Well then, what's it feel like, to raise a white child when your own child's at home...being looked after by somebody else? 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen's hand trembles as she sips from a glass of wate She glances sadly up to the picture of the young black ma

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I done raised seventeen kids in my life. Lookin' after white babies, that's what I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAE MOBLEY LEEFOLT, 2 1/2 years old, lies in a crib, cryi AIBILEEN enters. Her dark black skin contrasts angelicall with a brilliant white work dress, white panty hose and s

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know how to get them babies asleep, stop cryin' and go in the toilet bowl before they mommas even get outta bed in the mornin.' Aibileen lifts Mae Mobley out of her crib and pulls her i her expansive bosom.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Babies like fat. They like big fat legs too. That I know. Aibileen sits with Mae Mobley in a rocking chair.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I work from eight to four, six days a week. Ninety-five cents an hour comes to a hundred seventy-two dollars ever month. I do all the cooking, cleaning, washing, ironing and grocery shopping, but mostly, I take care a baby girl...And law, I worry she gone be fat. Ain't gonna be no beauty queen either. Mae Mobley reaches up and touches Aibileen's face. Aibile kisses her and whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You is kind. You is smart. You is important. Mae Mobley's mother, ELIZABETH LEEFOLT, 21 and lanky, ent wearing a green dress very much under construction. Pins double-stick tape hold it all together. Elizabeth has pointed features and a nest of teased, brit hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, bridge club's in an hour! Did you finish the chicken salad? 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and Hilly's deviled eggs. No paprika! Elizabeth rotates around like the Tin Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this dress look homemade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon when you finish, it won't. Elizabeth exits with her pinned hemline sloping at a good twenty degree angle. Aibileen shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Miss Leefolt still don't pick Baby Girl up but once a day. The birthin' blues had got holt a Miss Leefolt pretty hard. I done seen it happen plenty a times...once babies start havin' they own babies. And the young white ladies of Jackson...Oh, law, they was havin' some babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoking RECEPTIONIST, 50, leads EUGENIA "SKEETER" PHELA 23, across a smoke-filled news office. Even the light bul have yellowed.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But, not Miss Skeeter... Skeeter has very frizzy blond hair cut short above her shoulders. She carries a red satchel.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No babies...No man...And not lookin'. She wears flats, careful not to add more than a centimete her towering height. Dressed well, Skeeter tugs on her unfamiliar attire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The receptionist and Skeeter enter the office of MR. HARO BLACKLY, 68. He has greased, grey hair and the face of a mean man. Smoke pours into the room.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY
dialogues.text: Shut the Goddamn door! He snaps his fingers over a chair. Skeeter sits down.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They announced last week cigarettes'll kill you. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Blackly pours a pack of nuts into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's see what you got. Skeeter quickly hands Mr. Blackly a resumГ©. He skims it over, marking it violently with a red pen.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Murrah High Editor, Ole Miss Rebel Rouser Editor, double major, Junior League editor...Damn girl, didn't you have any fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that...important? Mr. Blackly sighs, hands the resumГ© back to Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY
dialogues.text: You got any references? Skeeter nods slowly. She takes a deep breath and pulls a letter out of her satchel. She hands it to Mr. Blackly. Mr. Blackly snatches the letter and reads it quickly, mouthing the words as he does. He drops the letter on his desk, and looks to Skeeter, flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That...is a rejection letter. Skeeter's face flushes hot and quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Missus Stein-

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY
dialogues.text: -STEIN?! Missus who? Skeeter points toward the letterhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine Stein, Senior Editor at Harper and Row Publishing. In New York. I'm going to be a serious writer, Mr. Blackly. So, when I applied to Harper and Row, Missus

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY
dialogues.text: -She told you "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until I gain some experience, Mr. Blackly! See, it says it right there at the end. "Great potential...Gain some experience and please apply again." Mr. Blackly pours the rest of the peanuts in his mouth. 5.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ...I guess you'll do. Can you clean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean? Mr. Blackly sees cigarette smoke bleeding under his door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY
dialogues.text: Clean! Mr. Blackly pulls up a box filled with letters and newspapers. He slams it down in front of Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Myrna's gone shit-house crazy on us, drunk hair spray or something. Read her past columns and all these letters. Answer them just like she did, nobody'll know the damn difference. Skeeter forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know who Miss Myrna is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read her articles all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACKLY
dialogues.text: Articles? Ha! It's a cleaning advice column, Miss Phelan. Eight bucks a week. Copy due Thursday. Mr. Blackly picks up the phone and starts yelling at some Skeeter excitedly grabs the box of letters and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HILLY HOLBROOK, 22, white and hefty, sits on a closed toi seat in a well-appointed bathroom. She's covered in red p and bows and has a round face topped by a perfect beehive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma! We're late for bridge! Hilly carefully rolls toilet paper out from its holder. S raises a pencil and places the tiniest dot imaginable on first and second sheets of paper.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Miss Hilly was the first of the babies to have a baby. And it must a come out of her like the eleventh commandment. `Cause once Miss Hilly had a baby, ever girl at the bridge table wanted one too. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She carefully rolls the paper back up in the roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny! Go get Momma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MINNY JACKSON, 33, black, plump and in uniform, rolls her eyes beneath a crystal chandelier. She shouts up the mahogany stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missus Walters?! You need help coming down? MISSUS WALTERS, 60, passes quietly behind Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm down! Minny jumps with a yelp, spins around.

dialogues.speaker: MISSUS WALTERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Been down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone give me a heart attack! Missus Walters ambles toward the closet door. Minny quick tries to turn her toward the front door. Missus Walters resists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny, I'm getting my coat. Missus Walters opens the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ninety degrees out there, Missus Walters. Missus Walters pulls out a red, wool coat with cheetah pr collar. The early stages of Alzheimer's have appeared, but Missus Walters is still quite proud at eighty percent capacity.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Once Missus Walters' arteries went hard, Miss Hilly moved her and Minny in with her. Fired the maid she had just to make room. See, Minny about the best cook in Mississippi, and Miss Hilly wanted her. Hilly's approach is marked by the whishing sound of her plaid, fat thighs. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nonchalantly grabs the coat from her mother and carri it out the door. Minny and Missus Walters follow. Minny carries a chocolat pie. Hilly barks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny, William took Billy out for ice cream. So, hurry back and get Billy down for his nap. No dilly dallying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Minny raises the pie behind Hilly's beehive, dreaming of smashing it into her head.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Minny my best friend. A old lady like me lucky to have her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen kneels next to Mae Mobley who sits on a small children's training toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's a tricky thing...you try to make a baby go in the toilet bowl before it's time. If theys can't get the hang of it, theys get to thinking low a theyselves. Mae Mobley sticks her lip out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drunk up two glasses a grape juice, I know you got to tee-tee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooo. Mae Mobley shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give you a cookie if you go. Tee-tee immediately sprinkles into the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Mobley! You going! Aibileen and Mae Mobley laugh excitedly as Elizabeth stor into the bathroom in her finished dress. The hemline now slants in the other direction. 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, the girls are pulling up, and the table isn't set!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Mobley go, Momma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in your room! Right now! Mae Mobley rises behind Aibileen's leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sorry. Elizabeth reaches down and scoops up Mae Mobley like a sa of potatoes. Mae Mobley looks to Aibileen over her mother's shoulder, eyes have welled up. Aibileen mouths "I love you" and blows her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Leefolt's small, wood paneled, two bedroom "ranch" is destined to become income property one day. FIVE YOUNG WOMEN, early 20s, and Elizabeth hover around t collapsible card tables arranged in the living room. Aibileen methodically arranges grapes on a platter of chi salad resting on Elizabeth's dining table. The table has small L-SHAPED CRACK in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I lost my own boy, Treelore, right before I started waitin' on the Leefolts... Elizabeth glances anxiously to the dining table then catc eyes with Aibileen, nodding ever so slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen carefully slides the platter over the L-SHAPED C making sure it's hidden.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After Treelore died, a bitter seed was planted inside a me. And I just didn't feel so accepting anymore. Hilly enters the front door holding Missus Walters coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, girls! 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hilly! Minny follows behind holding the pie and Missus Walters'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder) Put Momma in a chair before she breaks a hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not deaf yet, Hilly. Minny spies Aibileen in the corner and gives her a "here go" look as she lowers Missus Walters into a chair. Hilly approaches Aibileen with the coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, I want you to have this coat. It's too big for Momma now and it's way too expensive to put in the coat drive. Hilly extends the coat with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All yours. Aibileen takes the coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Try it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny plows through the swing door and reaches for Hilly' deviled eggs. Aibileen rushes in behind her wearing the cheetah collare coat. The sleeves are about a foot too short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on! Those are Miss Hilly's. Aibileen pulls another plate of eggs out of the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gots to have paprika on `em. Minny takes an egg. It disappears in a single bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Lord, but I'm gonna have to kill that woman. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen removes the coat and lays it over a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch yo mouth, Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a walking Christmas present with all them bows. Aibileen shakes with silent laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, now she gone to puttin' pencil marks on the toilet paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, law! Did she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-hum. But, I carry paper in from my own damn house. That fool don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Hilly cackle with a group of girls as Missu Walters sits on the couch watching "Guiding Light." Skeeter suddenly rushes through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Skeeter. JOLENE FRENCH, 24, approaches and hugs Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't Long-Haul- Skeeter. We didn't think you'd ever leave Ole Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's supposed to take four years, Jolene. Skeeter spins around to Hilly and Elizabeth with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. I had to stop by the cleaners and pick up my black dress. Hilly and Elizabeth look at Skeeter with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About supper club tonight...Honey, Stuart had to cancel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again? Hilly places her hand on Skeeter's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't get off the rig, Skeeter. It's offshore! Stuart is a very successful oil man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to think this Stuart is a figment of your imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh called his cousin down in Hattiesburg. He'll drive up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cousin with one eye?! Elizabeth nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess his black patch will match my dress. Just forget it. Skeeter storms off. Hilly glares at Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One eye?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen clears the dining table as bridge begins. Hilly, Elizabeth and Skeeter sit with Jolene. Skeeter tak deep breath and belts out her news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a job today... at The Jackson Journal! Everyone looks at Skeeter as if she just threw up on hers Finally, Hilly pats Skeeter on the leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd be a fool not to hire you. Jolene raises her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Skeeter...and her job. Last stop `til marriage. Hilly kicks Jolene under the table. 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Miss Myrna column. Have y'all read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no! But, I bet the poor girls without any help, in South Jackson, read it like the King James. Everyone laughs. Skeeter's forehead crinkles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, would you mind if I talk to Aibileen? To help me answer some of the letters? Just until I get a knack for it. Aibileen clears dishes as if she hasn't heard a thing. Elizabeth gets very still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen? My Aibileen? What can't you just get Constantine to help you? Skeeter looks to her lap and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constantine...quit us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Oh, my gosh! Skeeter nods her head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't want to talk about it. Okay? The girls nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway...I don't know how to answer these letters. Elizabeth looks to Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I mean as long as it doesn't interfere with her work. A phone rings. Elizabeth nods to Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen rushes in the kitchen and answers the phone. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leefolt residence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink, fuzzy slippers anchoring bare, sexy legs stand on a black and white check floor.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA FOOTE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Ah-hem. Hello, is Elizabeth in? Rising up a slim torso, sizeable cleavage bursts out of a pink robe's collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She having bridge club right now. May I take a message? CELIA FOOTE, 28, peroxide blonde, stands in all her count girl glory. She speaks with a thick, unrefined, Southern accent, mire insecurity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell her Celia Foote called again. I'll call back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Celia nervously twists herself around in the phone cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-hem. Miss? "Miss" strikes Aibileen as very odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for some help at my house. You know any maids looking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Celia Foote. Emerson 6-8-4. Bye, now. Celia hands up the phone with a frown and sips from a coc cola bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen enters the living room with a coffee pot. 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia Foote called again. Elizabeth leans over and touches Hilly's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never called her back, Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't take a hint, can she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Celia Foote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tacky girl Johnny married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl? I heard she's twenty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-hmm, worked concessions at a LSU game and sold him a hotdog. And, boy, he got a whole lot more. All the girls laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could have been you, Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And live thirty minutes outside of town? Anyway, I ran into her at the beauty parlor, and she had the nerve to ask if she could help with the children's benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we taking non-members? The benefit's gotten so big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but we're not telling her. Everyone laughs but Skeeter. Aibileen pours Skeeter a cup coffee. Skeeter looks up decidedly and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Aibileen. Hilly begins squirming in her seat, obviously making a po Elizabeth leans over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Hilly, I wish you'd just go use the bathroom. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-hem. I'm fine. Missus Walters shouts out from the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's upset cause the nigra uses the guest bath, and so do we. Elizabeth turns to Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, go check on Mae Mobley. Aibileen disappears. Elizabeth leans into Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go use mine and Raleigh's. Hilly hiss-whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Aibileen uses the guest bathroom, I'm sure she uses yours too.

dialogues.speaker: SHE DOES NOT
dialogues.text: Aibileen turns the corner in the hall and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you rather them take their business outside? Skeeter sees a reflection of Aibileen listening off of a picture in the hall. Skeeter tries to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did y'all see the cover of "Life" this week? Jackie's never looked

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Tell Raleigh every penny he spends on a colored's bathroom, he'll get back in spades when y'all sell. It's just plain dangerous. Everybody knows they carry different diseases than we do. I double. Elizabeth takes a puff of her cigarette and fidgets with cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't ask Raleigh until tax season. But, it would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I've drafted The Home Help Sanitation Initiative. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Home"...the what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a disease preventative bill that requires every white home to have a separate bathroom for the colored help. I've even notified the Surgeon General of Mississippi. I'll pass. Skeeter again glances at Aibileen. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we ought to just build you a bathroom outside, Hilly. The room grows eerily quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought not to joke about the colored situation. Hilly leans in toward Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do whatever it takes to protect our town. Your lead, Jolene. Jolene suddenly looks to a wall clock. She jumps up and throws her cards to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to skedaddle! Gotta get over to the station!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy's letting me do the weather tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia delicately prunes two rosebushes. Her long pink fingernails wrap easily around a pair of sheers. As Celia stands back to admire her work, We widen to see Foote estate. Ancient oaks dripping in Spanish moss surro a perfectly manicured lawn. "Tara" pales in comparison. Oddly, the two rosebushes have been planted in the center the lawn, jeopardizing the Antebellum Feng Shui.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now, Miss Celia had her a man. `Bout the best lookin' man in all of Mississippi. But, no baby and no friends. JOHNNY FOOTE, 23, Celia's ridiculously handsome husband, sneaks up behind her as he removes his jacket and tie. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roses look like weeds next to you. Celia turns with a yelp. She slaps him playfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, you scared the daylights out of me! Johnny begins kissing her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're home early. Celia pushes him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, I can't get any of your old friends from school to call me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, who cares, honey. We got all we need right here. Johnny kisses her again and lowers her to the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, honestly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor's orders. Johnny starts kissing Celia's breasts. She becomes uneasy and rolls out from under him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's taking us so long. I'm sorry. Johnny brushes hair from Celia's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we've never done it in the yard. Maybe that's the trick. Celia seductively bites her lower lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch my hair. Johnny's hand slides up her thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridge over, Skeeter smokes while watching through a wind as Minny arrives in Hilly's car. Skeeter blows smoke towa Hilly and Elizabeth saying good-bye. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sermon plays over an old AM radio nestled between canisters of sugar and flour. Aibileen enters with a stack of dirty coffee cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen? Aibileen becomes nervous at the sight of Skeeter alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had hoped to ask you myself if you could help me with the "Miss Myrna" letters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...Would you help me? Aibileen nods and looks out to Elizabeth on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Myrna gets it wrong lotta times. Be good to get it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Aibileen. I plan on splitting the pay with you, too. Aibileen doesn't respond. She grabs a basket of rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen...all that talk in there today. Hilly's talk I mean...I'm sorry you had to hear that. Aibileen quickly turns her back to Skeeter. A gospel choi begins singing on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Preacher Green's sermon on the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That reminds me so much of my maid growing up. Aibileen starts wiping down a serving tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constantine and me...were in church circle together. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter turns to Aibileen as she puts out her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She loved me like you love Mae Mobley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Skeeter moves closer to Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen? How could she just quit like that? Aibileen stops wiping and looks up to Skeeter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. When I got home from school last week, Momma said she had quit. Back in March to go live with her people up in Chicago. She didn't leave me a note or anything. Aibileen turns and resumes wiping the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you do that to Mae Mobley? Aibileen slowly turns back to Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. I couldn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have an address for her or anything? Aibileen shrugs her shoulders, reeling it all back in. Just then, Elizabeth walks into the kitchen holding paper stapled together. She looks between Aibileen and Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Did I interrupt something? Skeeter and Aibileen shake their heads. Elizabeth hands Skeeter the papers. Home Help Sanitation Initiative is written on the cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly wants this put in the League newsletter. Skeeter nods. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, I'll drop by at ten tomorrow to get started on Miss Myrna. Elizabeth looks at Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow is silver polishing day, so y'all make it quick, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter speeds down a country road lined with ancient oak trees in a white Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew I had said too much to Miss Skeeter, but Constantine's story weren't mine to tell. Some things a girl shouldn't have to know about her own mother. Her frizzy hair swirls about as she passes a truck full o cotton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter looks ahead and sees an OLDER BLACK WOMAN walking with a LITTLE BLONDE GIRL, 6. They hold hands. The black woman smiles and waves as Skeeter passes. When Skeeter looks in her rear view mirror, they're gone. Skeeter suddenly stops the car just short of an intersect gravel road. Skeeter slowly turns down the old road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter's car pulls into the overgrown yard of an old sha with a rusted-out tin roof. Two clapboard rooms are separated by an open breezeway. T front door is cracked opened. Skeeter gets out and walks toward Constantine's home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter enters to find only a small bed, dresser, table, rocking chair and a wood burning stove. Past intruders have long since taken anything of value. 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Skeeter approaches Constantine's bed, an OPOSSUM scurr out from underneath. Skeeter screams as the opossum runs out the door. Her eye suddenly catch something. Lying on the bed is an OLD CORN PIPE. Skeeter picks it up and brings it to her face. Her eyes begin to well up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter pulls in front of a grand antebellum home and par to the side of her family's graveyard. Skeeter carries her black dress up the stairs of a covere porch. An old black man with white hair, JAMESO, 70, tightens a porch swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jameso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Eugenia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter walks through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma! If the Smithsonian had wished to assemble the perfect antebellum home, Skeeter would be standing in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter enters and looks around curiously at an ARRAY OF resting atop a dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma? Skeeter's mother, CHARLOTTE BOUDREAU CANTELLE PHELAN, 50, glides into the room wearing a wig. Her floral print dres has a gazillion perfectly pressed pleats. Charlotte turns to a mirror and adjusts an auburn-colored `pixie' cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a little too young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little too everything. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte removes the wig with a sigh. Only now do we realize her decision to wear wigs isn't elective. Thinnin hair detracts from her perfectly made up face. Charlotte puts on a classic bouffant/flip in dark brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daddy bought me this dress in `58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, I want to ask you about

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Right after Ole Miss won the Sugar Bowl. Charlotte unzips the dress and takes it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you try it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What really happened? Charlotte winces with pain and grasps her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you...she went to live with her people in Chicago...Now, Skeeter, your mother is dying, and she wants to see you in this dress. Charlotte stands in her slip and bra holding the dress. Skeeter begins taking off her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could she just take off without telling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her not to write you. I didn't want you upset in the middle of final exams. Honey, we were just a job to her. With them it's all about money...Did I tell you Fanny Peatrow got engaged? After she got that teller job, her mother said she was just swimming in proposals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for "Fat Fanny Peatrow." She lowers the dress over Skeeter's head and zips it. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This looks precious on you! Four years ago my daughter went off to college, and what did she come home with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A diploma. A pretty piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly and Elizabeth have such lovely children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dropped out of college to become housewives, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only you'd show a little gumption, Eugenia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I did get a job today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writing...for The Jackson Journal. Charlotte plumps up the dress around Skeeter's behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. You can write my obituary. "Charlotte Phelan dead. Her daughter still single."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma, would it really be so terrible if I never met a husband? With that, Charlotte grabs Skeeter's hand and takes her t love seat. They sit. This is serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to...ask you something, Skeeter. I read the other day about how some girls...get unbalanced, start thinking these...well, unnatural thoughts. Charlotte begins to twist the handkerchief she holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you...do you...find men attractive? Are you having unnatural thoughts about... Charlotte shuts her eyes tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls or...or women? 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, this article says there's a cure, a special root tea. Skeeter jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, I want to be with girls as much as you wanna be with Jameso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eugenia! Skeeter storms out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlton's bringing Rebecca to dinner. Try to look presentable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Phelan dining room is lit solely by candles. The Phelan's new maid, PASCAGOLUA, 40, rolls a cart of casseroles around the table. Charlotte sits at the head of the table. She's having a b of broth. Skeeter sits next to her Father, ROBERT PHELAN, 60. Skeeter's brother, CARLTON, 25, sits next to his fiancГ©, REBECCA, 21. They're perfectly groomed with Hollywood goo looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you know about cleaning a house, Skeeter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a start, Carlton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted to write books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave your sister alone, Son. I'm proud of you, Sweetheart. Charlotte scoops up some broth with a spoon. 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the irony of it all. Givin' advice on how to keep up a home when she... Charlotte's spoon goes in her mouth. Pascagolua tries to scoop some sort of casserole covered almonds onto Skeeter's plate. Skeeter stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! No, Pascagolua! You couldn't have known this...But, see, I'm allergic to almonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Miss Eugenia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time I had an almond, I stopped liking men. Charlotte glares at Skeeter. Carlton lets out a chuckle. Rebecca is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Rebecca. They have a special root tea now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have pushed it, Young Lady! Pascagolua scurries off. Skeeter turns to her father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, what happened to Constantine? The room grows silent. Carlton looks down to his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah...well, Constantine went to live with her family. People move on, Skeeter. But I do wish she'd stayed down here with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. Skeeter looks to her mother who immediately busies hersel with scooping up more broth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, did you...fire her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't understand. Not until you've hired help of your own. 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raised me! Charlotte slaps the table and stands.

dialogues.speaker: SHE DID NOT
dialogues.text: Skeeter's eyes fill with tears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She worked here for twenty-nine years. Charlotte presses both hands to her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a colored thing, and I've put it behind me. Charlotte passes behind Rebecca and kisses her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Rebecca. My daughter has upset my cancerous ulcers. As Charlotte leaves the room, Rebecca looks at Skeeter li she's the worst person on earth. Skeeter gets up and storms off into the entry foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, 13 and lanky, wears a party dress. Despite a tig bun, her strong-willed hair has started to frizz. Skeeter's father and brother race down the stairs with suitcases. Carlton wears a varsity sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck down there, Carlton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have fun at the dance, Skeeter Legs. Robert and Carlton race outside as Charlotte enters, heal and glowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eugenia! You've grown another inch since breakfast. Go put on a dress that fits before that boy and his daddy come pick you up. A horn blows. Charlotte kisses Skeeter on the cheek and t looks over to CONSTANTINE, 50. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constantine stands tall. Her skin is black as night. Her eyes have a striking honey colored hue to them. She wears white sleeping gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray Carlton doesn't like LSU, Constantine. It's so far. It might be the last we see of him. The horn blows again. Charlotte is out the door. Skeeter turns to Constantine who is all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone be just you and me all weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits at a picnic table smoking a cigarette. Constantine smokes tobacco out of a corn pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just couldn't tell her I didn't get asked to the dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some things we should just keep to ourselves. Skeeter looks down to her long, bony legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already taller than the boys' basketball coach. How tall are you, Constantine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm five-thirteen, so quit feeling sorry for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma was third runner up in the Miss South Carolina pageant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Miss" what? Shoot, Child! You gone be "Miss Something Better." Constantine grabs Skeeter's hand and presses her thumb fi to her palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you listen. Your momma didn't pick her life. It pick her, and she done even know it. You gone do something big with yours. Bigger than your momma or your brother. Constantine lets go of Skeeter's palm and wipes a tear fr her face. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you? What did you want to be, Constantine? Constantine laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Child! We don't get to pick. This pick us, and that just how it is. Tight on Skeeter's face as Constantine gives her a big hu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter lies in bed staring holes into the ceiling as a rooster announces the morning. A sudden revelation washes over her. In a flash, Skeeter out of bed and running down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pascagoula tends to a skillet full of eggs next to a blac and white TV resting on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION
dialogues.text: Jolene French attempts to deliver the weather on WLBT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunny skies and a high of ninety- eight today with ninety-nine percent humidity. There's a slight chance of afternoon showers so y'all carry an umbrella. Jolene pivots to camera, lowers her chin and smiles. Skeeter runs past Pascagoula with a phone and disappears inside the pantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE STEIN, 45, hard but stylish, talks on the phone in large corner office. She lights a cigarette and swivels h chair toward the Manhattan skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gave you this idea, Miss Phelan? I'm...curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits on a huge sack of flour. A millennium's supp of can goods fills the shelves. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was...well, I was raised by a colored woman. I've seen how simple it can be and...well, how complex it can be, too...between the families and the help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to write something from the point of view of the help. These colored women raise white children, and then twenty years later those children become the employer. It's that irony, Miss Stein, that we love them and they love us yet...we don't even let them use the toilet in the house. Miss Stein's swivels her chair back around and sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret Mitchell glorified the mammy figure who dedicates her whole life to a white family but no one...ever asked Mammy how she felt about it. There is both undisguised hate for white women and an inexplicable love, but nobody ever talks about it down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, a side to this never before heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Charlotte knocks on the pantry door.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Skeeter, who are you talking to in there? Skeeter covers the mouth piece and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! Away! Skeeter slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, yes, their side of the story. Skeeter leans back against the shelves. 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother. She just dropped by to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, no maid in her right mind would ever tell you the truth. That's a hell of a risk in a place like Jackson, Mississippi. I watched them try to integrate your bus station on the news. Oy! They jammed fifty-five Negroes in a jail built for four. Skeeter panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have a maid. Skeeter can't believe what just came out of her mouth. Mi Stein rises and sits on the edge of her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? A negro maid has already agreed to talk to you? Skeeter blinks hard. No turning back now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I suppose I could read what you come up with. The book biz could use a little rattling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying I'll let you know if it's even worth pursuing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Miss Stein!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for God's sake, you're a twenty- four-year-old educated woman. Go get an apartment. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits across the table from Aibileen, reading the `Miss Myrna' letters. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, winds howl, and the sky grows dark. Jolene's forecast appears to be a bit off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Miss Myrna, How do I remove the rings from my fat, slovenly husband's shirt collar when he is such a pig and sweats like one too..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one she want a get rid of? Them rings or the husband? Skeeter chuckles and shrugs her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her a vinegar and Pine-Sol soak. Then let it set in the sun a bit. Skeeter writes this down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bout an hour. Let it dry. Skeeter keeps writing. Aibileen notices something outside Hilly walks into the Leefolt backyard with her son, BILLY perched on her hip. A CONTRACTOR, 30s, follows holding a set of plans. Skeeter turns to the open window. It's already started to sprinkle outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Build it just like the one at my house, right against the garage. The contractor nods. Lightning strikes, thunder cracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, mercy! Hilly is off and running with Billy. Skeeter seizes the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, do you ever wish you could...change things? Aibileen turns slowly from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, all that talk yesterday and now with what Hilly's up to. Aibileen's eyes fall to the floor. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everthing's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My momma fired Constantine. Thank you for telling me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never tolt you that! Aibileen jumps up as another crack of thunder sounds out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, I have an idea...Something I want to write about...But I need your help. Skeeter rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to interview you...about what it is like to work as a maid. Aibileen stops at the refrigerator, gripping the life out its handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to do a book of interviews about working for white families. Show what it's like to work for, say...Elizabeth. Aibileen begins to perspire. She grabs the counter to ste herself, then moves toward her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what'd happen to me if Miss Leefolt knew I was tellin' stories on her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking we wouldn't tell her. The other maids will have to keep it secret, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other maids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping to get four or five. To really show what it's like in Jackson. To see what y'all get paid, the babies, the bathrooms, the good and the bad. Aibileen shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They set my cousin Shinelle's car on fire just cause she went down to the voting station. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A book has never been written like this, Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Cause they's a reason. I do this with you, I might as well burn my own house down. Bam! The front door slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soaking wet, Elizabeth and her husband, RALEIGH, 25, stan toe to toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put up with the new clothes and all the damn trips to New Orleans, but this takes the goddamn cake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll confuse Mae Mobley if she sees Aibileen going inside. And we can't risk her health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen hears Mae Mobley crying, but she is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly spoke to the Surgeon General! She also said it'll add value to our home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! Mae Mobley can just go to college in that bathroom, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, Hilly's covering the cost...and said you can just do William's taxes to pay her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't take orders from the Holbrooks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh storms in and is surprised to see Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter? How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fix me a sandwich, Aibileen. Raleigh storms out as Elizabeth charges into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, Mae Mobley's crying her eyes out! Aibileen runs off. Elizabeth sees Skeeter and tries to compose herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter...Hello. I'm sorry but I think it's best if you leave now. Skeeter gathers her things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...I don't think this Miss Myrna thing is gonna work out with Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm has escalated. The Holbrook house is without power. Hilly runs around lighting candles. Missus Walters lies on the couch while Minny fans her wit newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making it a lot hotter flapping your arm like that. Minny stops and begins squirming with discomfort. Missus Walters notices her looking out to the garage bathroom. Lightning strikes. Leaves blow across the yard. Hilly plo down in a chair with a candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should do it. Minny, go get me and Momma some iced tea. Minny hesitates. She gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...Miss Hilly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. As Minny turns, Missus Walters calls out to her. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go on ahead and use the guest bath, Minny. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for crying out loud. It's just a little rain. She can go get an umbrella up in William's Study!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe she was working for me before you dragged us both here. Minny looks outside just as wind slams an aluminum lawn c against the garage bathroom. Boom! Another crash of thunder. Large hail stones begin falling in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gone get your tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny sneaks into the guest bath with a candle and shuts door. She carefully lowers the seat and sits. Relief spreads across her face. There's a knock on the door. She freezes.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Minny? Minny panics, staying completely quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly leans into the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MINNYYYY, are you in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sitting down? Minny gets up quickly and flushes the toilet. Hilly beats the door.

dialogues.speaker: GET OFF OF MY TOILET
dialogues.text: Outside the house, an eerie, groaning sound, much like a freight train, intensifies. The top of a huge tree snaps off and falls against the ho shattering a window. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny crouches down and covers her head. A draft sucks th candle's flame toward the bottom of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen sits with Mae Mobley against an interior wall, holding a mattress on top of them and humming in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On top a Minny losin' her tenth job, eighteen people died in Jackson that day. Ten white. Eight black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter stands in her backyard facing Jackson. Cool winds head toward the dark, swirling horizon. In the distance, lightning strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia leans on the porch railing, gazing helplessly as th relentless hail storm pummels her two rosebushes.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: God don't pay no mind to color or class once he sets a tornado loose. Within seconds, the rose blossoms are gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BATHROOM/BACKYARD, (INTERCUT)
dialogues.text: Aibileen uses the newly completed bathroom Hilly has buil the garage. The walls consist of unpainted plywood with a small window hugging the ceiling. Beads of sweat glisten on Aibileen's forehead under a sin bulb hanging above.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Soon after, that bitter seed inside of me had sprout and was growing fast... Well into her second pregnancy, Elizabeth exits the house with Mae Mobley at her side. She wears an awful, homemade maternity dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, Aibileen. Mae Mobley's up, and I'm off to the doctor. Aibileen reaches behind and flushes the toilet. Mae Moble gets excited and points to the garage bathroom. 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibee bafroom, Momma! Mae Mobley walks toward the bathroom and calls out.

dialogues.speaker: MAE MOBLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aibee? Elizabeth grabs her and forces her down on the back step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right there, Baby Girl. Aibileen pulls up her panty-hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen waits with YULE MAY, 45, as well as other maids black males at a bus stop. Yule May is tall, pretty and graceful. Her hair is pulled tightly into a bun. Skeeter walks down the sidewalk toward them. She and Aibileen catch eyes. Skeeter waves. Yule May inches away from Aibileen. One BLACK MAN in particular looks with concern as Skeeter walks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Aibileen. Aibileen nods nervously, looking at the other domestics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you? A bus pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got some "Miss Myrna" questions for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Yule May and others board. Skeeter grabs Aibileen's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Aibileen signals to Yule May to go on ahead without her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. The bus pulls away. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let me interview you. I know it's scary, but I really believe this has to be done. We'll be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This already ain't careful, Miss Skeeter. You not knowing that is what scares me most. I'm sorry. Skeeter hands Aibileen a piece of paper with her phone nu written on it. Aibileen turns and walks off down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark outside, Aibileen approaches another, more integrate bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know pretty well what happens if the white ladies found out we was writing about them. Womens, they ain't like men. Women don`t beat you with a stick. Naw, they like to keep they hands clean. Got a shiny set a tools they use, sharp as witches' fingernails. As Aibileen ambles toward a bench, TWO WHITE WOMEN in nur uniforms push in front of her and sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits at a long table surrounded by books piled hi as if to provide a shield of sorts. Lying before her, is an old, thin, onionskin booklet curl at the edges. It's titled: "Compilation of Jim Crow Laws of the South" Skeeter opens the booklet and begins reading.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Any person printing, publishing or circulating written matter urging for public acceptance of social equality between whites and negroes is subject to imprisonment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen sits at a table wearing a nightgown. She careful combs and styles her wig for work in the morning. Her real hair is bound tightly in dozens of tightly bound nubs. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rotary wall phone rings. Aibileen hangs the wig on he chair and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny is hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Aibileen! I went and did it now! Minny wraps a hand up in the phone cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Hilly been tellin' everbody in town I stole a candelabra! That's why I can't get no job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everbody know you honest, Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but I got her back...I did something awful, Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you did?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny stands on Hilly's porch holding a chocolate pie.

dialogues.speaker: MINNY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I cain't tell! I ain't tellin' nobody! I done a terrible awful thing to that woman. And now she knows what I did! Hilly answers the door and snarls at Minny. Minny present the pie and says "I am sorry." Hilly waves Minny inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got what she deserve, Aibileen. But, now I ain't gone never get no work again...Leroy gone kill me. Minny's husband, LEROY, 40, approaches behind Minny. Minn slowly turns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen hears a loud slap and Minny's phone dropping to floor. Yelling and screaming follows. 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny! She can't bear to listen and hangs up the phone. She sees Skeeter's phone number taped to the wall. Aibileen's breath becomes heavy. Anger wells inside her. She picks up the phone again and begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing a black scarf over her hair and clutching her red satchel, Skeeter approaches a small, one-story wood structure. White paint peels, hydrangeas fill the yard. Skeeter spies an old pickup truck parked on the side of Aibileen's house, completely covered in years of dust. Skeeter checks over her shoulder several times. The porch steps creak under her big feet. Aibileen quickly opens the door and waves her inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen wears the same yellow dress she wore in the firs scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I parked way up on State Street and caught a cab here like you asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got dropped two streets over? Skeeter nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, I now know it's against the law for us to meet like this. Skeeter stares Aibileen up and down. Aibileen self- consciously flattens our her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen you out of uniform before. You look nice, Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Aibileen motions for Skeeter to sit on a narrow sofa behi coffee table covered in hand-tatted lace. A tray holds a teapot, two cups that don't match and cook resting on folded napkins. As Aibileen pours the tea, her hand shakes. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I've never had a white person in my house before. Skeeter sips her tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been in a colored person's home before. I think we're both doing great. This tea is really nice. Aibileen watches as Skeeter takes a bite of the cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Skeeter, What if...What if you don't like what I got to say? About white peoples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...this isn't about my opinion. It doesn't matter how I feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gone have to change my name. Mine, Miss Leefolt's, everbody's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody? So, you know other maids who might be interested? Aibileen is quiet for a moment. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gone be hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Minny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny got her some stories, sho nuff. But, she ain't real keen on talking to white peoples right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We continue with the interview seen on page one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it feel like, to raise a white child when your own child's at home, being...looked after by somebody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feel...Uh. Aibileen glances up to the framed picture of Treelore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your son? 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. He dead two years now. Got run over at the lumber yard. Lungs were crushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. That's horrible. And, Aibileen, you don't have to call me "ma'am." Not here anyway. Aibileen nods. Skeeter stares at her list of questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to talk about the bathroom? Or, about Elizab--Miss Leefolt? Anything about the way she pays you? Has she ever yelled at you in front of Mae Mobley? Aibileen shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I- Aibileen covers her mouth with her hand. Skeeter becomes disgusted with herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I am. She pulls out a stack of Miss Myrna letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just do a couple of Miss Myrna letters, and I'll run on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might write my stories down and read them to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It no different than writing down my prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say your prayers aloud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prayer like electricity. It keep life going. Writing it down make it more powerful. Lot a ailing, sick peoples in this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get a chance to pray for Treelore. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God took him fast `cause he didn't want to argue with me. He was just twenty-four years old. The best part of a person's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he'd like we's doing this. He always said we gone have a writer in the family one day...After my prayers last night, I got some stories down too. Skeeter nods. Aibileen opens her notebook and reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My first white baby to ever look after was named Alton Carrington Speers. It was 1938, and I'd just turned fourteen years old. Daddy had left us, so I dropped out a school to help momma with the bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A congregation of three hundred stand singing lively with large choir. Aibileen stands next to Yule May and is whispering in her ear. Yule suddenly leans back, shocked, shaking her head "no." Minny watches from two pews back. Her curiosity is peaked

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Alton's momma died a lung disease. I loved that baby, and he loved me. That's when I learned I could make children feel proud of theyselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Stein sits at her desk reading Aibileen's stories.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Alton used to always be asking me how come I's black...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just ate him up, so one time I told him it cause I drank too much coffee. Oh, law, you should a seen his face. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter laughs as she writes down Aibileen's story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is great. You have no idea how much I appreciate this...But I just have to ask. What changed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Hilly Holbrook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly stands at a podium banging a gavel. The pleats of h navy blue sailor's number fan out like an accordion. A room full of JUNIOR LEAGUE MEMBERS sits up and quiets d Half the girls are pregnant and most all drink TAB and ar smoking. Skeeter sits in the back next to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're running behind on our "coat drive," girls. So hurry up and clean out those closets...But our Christmas Benefit, however, is right on schedule as y'all have already filled all our baked goods raffle slots. The girls applaud, turning to each other with praise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all think we can put a dent in the African Children's hunger this year? More applause. Those who aren't pregnant, stand. Hilly beams. Elizabeth nudges Skeeter out of her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now for some exciting news...I wanted y'all to be the first to know...My William is seeking election to the State Senate this November! Now, even the pregnant women stand. Elizabeth grabs Skeeter's arm and pulls herself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's runnin' on a platform of health. Protecting our children. Protecting our way of life. So, I, with William, have drafted The Home Health Sanitation Initiative. This sets off a room of whispers. 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, when can we expect to see the initiative in the newsletter? I gave it to you a month ago. Everyone turns to Skeeter. Elizabeth panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave that to you myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, ah...Well, I-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you please stand, Skeeter? As Skeeter rises, several women shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have it in there soon. Skeeter glances at the initiative tucked in her satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter turns a corner and sees Hilly leaning on her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly? Do you need a ride? Hilly shakes her head with little emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about the newsletter. Hilly nods. A soft smile begins to form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Momma being sick and- Hilly erupts with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming! Oh, Skeeter, he's definitely coming this time. This Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Hilly, he's cancelled twice before. Maybe it's a sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare say that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I won't be his type. Hilly grabs Skeeter by the shoulders. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your time, Skeeter. And damnit, I'm not going to let you miss this just because your mother convinced you you're not good enough for somebody like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny is again wearing her maid's uniform. She puts two plates of food down on the kitchen table. She sits next to her daughter, SUGAR, 15. Sugar wears a brand-spanking-new maids's uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat up, Girl. Miss Woodra's like to not feed ya on try-out day. Sugar takes a bite of toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still say you're too young to be waitin' on white peoples...Now, Sugar, I want you to listen to me, and you listen to me good. Minny grabs Sugar's face and looks her right in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the rules for working in a white lady's house. Sugar jerks her face away and sticks her lip out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rule Number One: Don't you ever let White Lady find you sittin' on her toilet. Sugar nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number Two: You keep your nose out of White Lady's problems, and don't cry to her with yours. White people ain't your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny steps off a bus and walks down an old country road.

dialogues.speaker: MINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Number Three: When you're cooking white food, taste it with a different spoon. They see you put the tasting spoon back in the pot, might as well throw it all out. Spoon, too. 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny approaches the Foote estate. She stops just short o stairs leading up to the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: MINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Four: You use the same cup, same fork, same plate every day. Minny takes her first step on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Five: Don't hit her kids. White people do they own spanking. Minny slowly raises her hand to knock on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Six: No sass-mouthing! Minny knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number six, Minny. Number six. The door flies open. Celia Foote answers. She's covered i tight pink clothes. Flour covers her face and hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there! I'm Celia Rae Foote. Aibileen said you'd be on time. Minny looks down disapprovingly to Celia's bare feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you a cold Coca-Cola?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I'm Minny Jackson... You...cooking something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those upsidedown cakes from the magazine. It ain't workin' out too good. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny enters behind Celia gawking at the flour massacre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the hell- Minny catches herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuck it in, Minny. Tuck it in. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I have some learnin' to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny and Celia enter a huge dining room. Minny gawks at dusty mahogany table surrounded by twelve chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny's momma wouldn't let me decorate a thing. If I had my way, this house would have wall to wall white carpet with gold trim and none of this old stuff. Minny spies a framed battle-worn Confederate flag complet with bullet holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you from? Celia lowers her head in shame...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar Ditch. It's near Memphis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Sugar Ditch. My cousin live there. Celia changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go meet Oscar! Celia grabs Minny's hand. Annoyed, Minny pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny stands at the base of a massive, stuffed Grizzly be It clears the twelve-foot ceiling by an inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny's granddaddy shot him up in Montana back in 1910 with Teddy Roosevelt. Celia points to fifteen guns mounted behind Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got five bedrooms and bathrooms here in the main house. The pool house has two more beds and baths. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you gone have some chillins, start fillin' up all these beds? Celia swallows hard. She places her hand on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant now. Minny steps back and surveys Celia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone be eatin' for two. Double the cookin'. Celia slumps her shoulders as she looks around the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's an awful lot to do. Five other maids have already turned me down...Can I at least give you some bus money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you hear me say I don't wanna clean this house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? So...You'll do it?! Before Minny can nod. Celia throws her arms around her. Minny backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No huggin', now. No huggin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. This is my first time hiring a maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to talk about some things first. I work Sunday through Friday. Celia bites her pinky nail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't come at all on weekends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. What time you want me here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After eight, and you have to leave at four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Now what your husband say you can pay? Celia looks away. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny doesn't know I'm bringing in help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's Mr. Johnny gone do if he comes home and finds a colored woman up in his kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that I'd be fibbing. I just want him to think I can do this on my own...I need some help `til I get the hang of it. I need a maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A course you do. Last one done got shot in the head. Minny sniffs the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia, I think you done burned up yo cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia grabs a rag off the sink and jerks the cake out of oven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oww! Dawgonit! She drops the burnt cake on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't use no wet towel on a hot pan. Minny grabs a dry towel and picks up the cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take this burnt up cake with me so Mister Johnny don't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen removes Mae Mobley's wet cloth diaper on a chang table. Mae Mobley's behind is covered with inflamed diape rash. Aibileen shakes her head. Elizabeth enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off, Aibileen. Don't forget Raleigh wants pot roast tonight. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Aibileen's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter works with a typewriter now. Aibileen, more casua dressed than before, waits for Skeeter to finish typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon I'm ready...to talk about Miss Leefolt now. Skeeter stops typing and looks up. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby girl don't get her diaper changed `til I get there in the morning. That's `bout ten hours she gots to sit in her mess. I be so worried about her on my day off. I always come in an hour early on Mondays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte sits at a table sorting through mail as Skeeter enters and grabs an apple

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Miss Leefolt pregnant again, too. And, law, I pray this child turn out good. It a lonely road if a momma don't think theys child is pretty. Charlotte glances down disapprovingly at the dingy, huara shoes on Skeeter's feet. Skeeter heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Skeeter? Skeeter turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bible study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a Saturday night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma, God doesn't care what day of the week it is. Skeeter walks out the back door as Charlotte shakes her h 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, Elizabeth and Jolene French stand with Hilly's contractor. He unrolls a set of bathroom plans. Hilly and Elizabeth look to Jolene and nod approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter's typing slows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Leefolt be spending so much time keeping up with the society ladies, she done forgot the child she got now. Just then Minny barges through the kitchen back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen! Minny stops cold in her tracks at the sight of Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yule May told me what y'all up to. Aibileen nods. Minny's face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medgar Evers live five minutes away. They blew up his carport last night. For talking! Minny scowls at Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think colored people need your help? You white. Why you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all working for the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you just want to get her in trouble. Skeeter is petrified. Her face reddens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to show her perspective...so people might understand what it's like from your side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's a real Fourth of July picnic. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what we dream a doing all weekend long, get back in they house to polish the silver. And we just love not getting minimum wage or Social Security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Minny. Maybe things might

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What law's gonna say you gotta be nice to your maid? And another thing, I don't want my children going to school with white kids. And I don't care a thing about votin.' Only thing black mens get elected to is Deacon of the church.
