dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to do this, Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You damn right I don't! You two givin' me the heart palpitations. Minny storms out the back door. Skeeter looks like she mi get sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that was a good mood. Minny immediately storms back in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right...I'm gone do it. I just want to make sure you know this ain't no game we're playing here. Skeeter nods, trembling as Minny slides a chair in the mi of the kitchen and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slide your chair out from under that table and face me. I want to see you square on at all times. Still trembling, Skeeter slides her chair from the table just sits there staring at Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I's got to come up with your questions, too?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's begin...begin with...with where you were born. Aibileen grabs her notebook and begins writing. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belzoni, Mississippi on my great- auntie's sofa. Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny talks a mile a minute. Aibileen continues writing.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Once Minny got to talking `bout food, she liked to never stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put the green beans in first, then I go on and get the pork chops going cause, mmm-mmm, I like my chops hot out the pan. Just as Aibileen fills the first notebook, Skeeter hands another from her satchel.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But when she got to talking about the white ladies, it took all night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first signs of morning sun filter into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh, Minny, I'm gone give you a week paid vacation." Now, I ain't had no paid vacation in my life. A week later, I come back and they'd moved to Mobile. "Miss Lazy Fingers" scared I'd find a new job before she moved... Minny spins around to Aibileen with sudden realization...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gots to get more maids! Minny stands. Skeeter's eyes widen with hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but it hard, Minny. Mind racing, Minny flies out the door without a word. Aibileen turns to Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gone and done it now. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Stein discusses Aibileen and Minny's stories with Skeeter on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this "Sarah Ross." She can kvetch but not complain too much.

dialogues.speaker: INT- PHELAN PLANTATION, (INTERCUT)
dialogues.text: Skeeter nods rapidly as if she knows what "kvetch" means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this "Bertha"...she's got chutzpah. I'll give her that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...you liked it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eugenia, Martin Luther King just invited the country to march with him in D.C. this August. This many negroes and whites haven't worked together since "Gone with the Wind."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean you'll publish it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that. My advice is to write it fast before this civil rights thing blows over. I need it by New Year's, and don't send me anything more until you have twelve maids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny, Aibileen and Skeeter sit at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen and I done asked everbody we know. Thirty-one maids. Everbody too scared, think we crazy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we might as well stop! 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got plenty a stories, Miss Skeeter. Just write`em down and invent a maid that said it. We already making up everbody's name. Make up the maids, too. Skeeter jumps up from her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do that! Aibileen and Minny lean back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean...I would never do that. It wouldn't be real. It's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give up on us, Miss Skeeter. Skeeter softens and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Thank you both for trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter delivers the "Miss Myrna" columns to the receptionist, who hands her back a paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia and Minny stand at a fried chicken assembly line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you cook? Minny dips pieces chicken in an egg wash, then drops them a paper bag. A puff of flour rises out of the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can cook corn pone, boil potatoes, and do grits. Minny bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't have electric current where I was raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I reckon if there's anything you ought to know `bout cooking... Minny holds up a can of Crisco. 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's this. The most important invention since they put mayonnaise in a jar. You don't even know the things you can do with this here can. Celia peers into the skillet as Minny spoons out a mound Crisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How pretty. Looks like frosting. Minny rolls her eyes and hands Celia the bag of Chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shake that. Celia starts shaking the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is fun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny sits down at the table with a plate of chicken. Cel sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks so good! I'm starved. Aggravated, Minny stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You supposed to eat in the dining room, Miss Celia. That how it works. Minny grabs Celia's plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, I'll take your plate in the dinin' room for ya. Want tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine right here, Minny. Minny sits back down with a sigh. Celia touches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm real grateful you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia, you got a lot more to be grateful for than me. A car is heard pulling up in the driveway. Minny panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Johnny?! 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! Hide! Minny slides down underneath the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...It's just the florist. Johnny must have sent me flowers. Minny pulls herself up off the floor. She's mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia, I ain't playin' around no more! He gone catch me here and shoot me dead right here on this no- wax floor! You gots to tell him. Ain't he wondering how the cooking so good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. Maybe we ought to burn the chicken a little. The doorbell rings. Celia runs off to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny don't burn chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits with a towel draped across her shoulders. Charlotte, now in an auburn wig, squirts mounds of goo fr pink tube onto Skeeter's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is bound to work, Sweetie. It even smells expensive. She begins twisting Skeeter's hair into gooey spikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel the hope in your fingers. Skeeter resembles a papier machГ© starfish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you not know his last name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's William's cousin. That's all I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just so sweet of Hilly. Charlotte takes a drag from her cigarette, then lifts up silver machine complete with power cord and rubber hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?! 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shinolator! It cost eleven dollars. I'm a good mother. Charlotte puts a shower cap device on Skeeter's head and reads from the Shinolator manual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Miracle Straitening Cap" must remain on the head for two hours."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours?! Charlotte flips a switch and takes another drag. The mach groans to life. Skeeter's cap inflates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have Pascagoula bring you a magazine. Skeeter snatches her mother's cigarette and takes a drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits under the Shinolator buried in a magazine. Pascagoula enters and sets down a glass of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Constantine. Do you think this dress is cute? Skeeter holds the magazine up to Pascagoula. Only now doe she realize what she's said and done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Thanks, Pascagoula. Pascagoula nods and starts to walk away then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew Constantine. She was a mighty fine woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shinolator was a success. Skeeter's hair is straight, silky and beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've shrunk five inches. You'll be able to wear heels tonight. Charlotte looks down to the huarache shoes on Skeeter's f and rushes to the closet. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not leaving this house in those awful, Mexican, man shoes. Charlotte pulls out a dress and pair of heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is he picking you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's meeting me at Hilly's. Can I take the Cadillac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We promised Carlton the Cadillac tonight. So, William's cousin will just have to come get you himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hooked to the motor grader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter pulls away in a rusted 1941 Chevy farm truck with huge motor grader attached. Charlotte runs next to the truck. Her wig is askew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mope. Remember to smile! Skeeter floors it. Charlotte runs faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, don't sit like some squaw Indian. Cross! Your! Ankles! Skeeter leaves her mother in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chunks of mud fly off the tires. The June sun has set the truck's interior at a stubborn 115 degrees. Skeeter has no choice but to lower her window. The Shinolator meets its match. A mangy, STRAY CAT suddenly jumps out in the road. When towing 10,000 pounds of farm equipment, slowing down quic isn't an option. 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud thud sounds out from the truck's grill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, her husband, WILLIAM, and Skeeter's date, STUART WHITWORTH, drink high balls and eat cheese in the Holbroo parlor. Gold swag curtains hang on the windows. Balding and pudgy, only William's family money once made a desirable bachelor. Stuart, on the other hand, is very handsome, the "Marlboro Man" in a well-tailored suit. Yule May (who we met earlier at church with Aibileen) now works for Hilly. She clears empty glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your daddy's endorsement, I can win that Senate seat. Stuart feigns interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to him. Ice slams against Stuart's teeth as he downs his drink. Hilly pats William's leg then turns with concern to a grandfather clock announcing half past the hour. The front door flies open. Skeeter enters completely out breath and sweaty. Her HAIR HAS TRIPLED IN SIZE. She wave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. As Hilly races toward Skeeter, William and Stuart stand. Stuart is as tall as he is handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, we'll be right back. Y'all talk about quarterbacks or something. Yule May, get Miss Skeeter a Coca Cola. Yule May runs off. Hilly pulls Skeeter down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits on the toilet downing a Coca-Cola. Hilly twi the last of Skeeter's hair into giant rollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, you don't even have on lipstick! Skeeter dabs her armpits. 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so goddamn awful. I hit a cat. Hilly sprays Final Net.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...What do you think of him? Skeeter applies lipstick. Hilly removes the rollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks handsome. Skeeter stands up and does a twirl for Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, give it to me. One to ten? Hilly sprays Skeeter with perfume and stands back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?! Seven? Hilly nods, lets out a little squeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, you're beautiful. Just go on out there...you're gonna do great. It's your time, Skeeter. I just know it. Hilly hugs Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, William, Stuart and Skeeter sit at a round table adorned with white linens, silver and fine china. The room buzzes with Jackson's elite all trying to be not as a JAZZ QUARTET plays softly in a corner. A WAITER approaches. Stuart leans into Skeeter without making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just water, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Old Kentucky straight...with a water back...Make that two backs. 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THANKS?! So...you went to Alabama? Stuart nods. Hilly rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Roll Tide." We still love him. Hilly pinches Stuart on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're in the oil business. Hilly says you're a rigsite leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money's good. If that's what you really want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I- Skeeter and Hilly watch as Stuart's and William's eyes fi the front of the restaurant. Celia and Johnny have entered. Celia wears a tight green dress and the reddest lipstick ever put in a tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that your old boyfriend, Hilly? Johnny Foote? Hilly scowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's his girl? Lord, she's hotter than Delta asphalt. Celia spots Hilly and gives a self-conscious wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William! The Lieutenant Governor just walked in. Hilly jumps up and pulls William away. The waiter returns with Stuart's drink and the water backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do you do with your time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I write a...a domestic maintenance column for the Jackson Journal. Stuart smirks, taking a huge sip of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean housekeeping? Skeeter nods and grabs her water. 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I can't think of anything worse than reading a cleaning column. Except maybe writing one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly and William finish shaking hands with the Lieutenan Governor. As he walks away, Hilly shouts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd love your support on election day! Celia and Johnny walk up. Hilly stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, you look lovely tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, have you ever met Celia? William steps forward and shakes Celia's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. Hilly grabs the crook of William's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie, we need to go order our dinners. Celia musters up all the courage inside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, did you ever get the messages that I've been calling you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I would love to help with the benefit. I have a lovely hand if you need invitations addressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Save the dates" were mailed weeks ago...You didn't get one? Celia shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail's a lot slower way out there in the country, huh? 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, come on, before they run out of Trout Almondine. Hilly pulls William away. Johnny grabs Celia's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a ploy to find a husband...becoming an expert on keeping house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you must be a genius. You figured out my whole scheme. Skeeter fumes as Hilly and William return and sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd we miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that what you women from Ole Miss major in? Professional husband hunting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but were you dropped on your head as an infant? Stuart blinks and then smiles, somewhat impressed. Desper to change the subject, Hilly claps her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Is? Hungry? Skeeter stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me! A kiss from God couldn't turn this `frog' into a `prince.' Tables begin to stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you a `princess,' Sweetheart! As Skeeter walks away, she purposefully slides her purse a glass of water, knocking it over into Stuart's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly and William each have a section of newspaper in the face as Yule May clears breakfast dishes. Yule May linger nervously. 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run on, now, Yule May. Got a big crowd coming for Miss Leefolt's baby shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Hilly, I would like to ask you and Mister William something. Hilly lowers her paper and nods. Yule May begins wrenchin her hands.

dialogues.speaker: YULE MAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My twin boys finished high school, both on the honor roll...My husband and I have been saving for years to send them to college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Only now does William lower his paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are short seventy-five dollars on one of the tuitions. William stands up, kisses Hilly on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm late. Gotta go. William leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now...We're faced with having to choose. Which son gets to go...if we don't find all the money. Hilly draws in a deep breath as does Yule May.

dialogues.speaker: YULE MAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you consider givin' us a loan? I'll...I'll work for free until it's paid off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not working for free, Yule May. That's paying off a debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a Christian, I'm going to do you a favor. Yule May's eyes widen as a hopeful smile forms. 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God doesn't give charity to those who are well and able. You need to come up with this money on your own. You'll thank me one day. Hilly raises the paper up to her face as Yule May exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny and Aibileen, in uniform, push carts side by side i the grocery store. The white shoppers are dressed casuall Other maids in the store (all required to be in uniform w shopping) keep quietly to themselves. White women smile and chat with one another as they meand down the aisles as if the black maids aren't even there. Minny suddenly spots Celia in the produce section. She pu Aibileen close as they peer around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's her. Aibileen's mouth drops open at the sight of Celia's short and tight sweater. Celia is having trouble selecting produce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, she's trying to shop. Celia walks up to a maid, grabs her, and pulls her to the tomatoes. The maid, clearly uncomfortable, selects a toma hands it to Celia, and scurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Doll!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia just don't see `em. The lines. Not between us, Miss Hilly, nobody. Aibileen just nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you so quiet for? I know you got a opinion `bout all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gone accuse me a philosophizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't afraid a no philosophy. 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in lines anymore. Lines is in our heads `cause people like Miss Hilly try to make us believe they there. Celia squeezes a canteloupe with another scared maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they there. I know. I get punished for crossing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen and Minny continue their conversation while wait with several other maids at a bus stop in front of the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotta of folk think if you talk back to your husband, you crossed a line...need to be punished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I ain't studying no line like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause it ain't there. `Cept in Leroy's head. Lines between black and white ain't there either. Minny and Aibileen watch as Celia exits the store with he groceries and prances toward her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I ain't crossing no line if I tell Miss Celia she ain't good enough for Miss Hilly? Tell her she ain't in Miss Hilly's league?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I'm saying is kindness don't have no boundaries. Just then, MYRLIE EVERS, 30, (Medgar Evers wife) approach the bus stop with her three Children. SONS, 10 and 3, and DAUGHTER, 8. Aibileen and Minny nod as the Evers walk past and sit on bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law, the Evers children have gotten so big!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause they happy. Myrlie got her a good man...And you better not try to say they ain't no line between her Medgar and my Leroy. 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You got me. A bus pulls up and the doors open. Minny, Aibileen and th other maids step aside to let the Evers family board firs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen has come along to aid Yule May with Elizabeth's shower. A table is set in the middle of the yard covered in white linens and Hilly's best sliver. Hilly's son sits on her lap. The other girls' children we bathing suits jumping noisily in and out of two plastic k pools. Yule May clears cake plates while Aibileen removes crumbs with a sterling crumb scraper. Mae Mobley wanders up to the table. Her belly almost look distended crammed inside last year's one piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Mo hungry, Momma. Elizabeth turns to Mae Mobley but never gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's always hungry. All the women laugh except for Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know she can hear you, Elizabeth? Elizabeth looks down to her plate. Aibileen sets down the scraper and kneels down to Mae Mobley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on cut you some cake, Baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, we gave that scraper to Hilly and William for their wedding present. Chantilly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It so pretty. Hilly begins bouncing William Jr. on her knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, are you enjoying your new bathroom over at Elizabeth's? Hilly nods with a tight smile and glances to the ground a Skeeter's red satchel. 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to have your own, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Separate but equal. That's what Ross Barnett says, and you can't argue with the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in Mississippi. Birthplace of modern day government. Hilly narrows her eyes at Skeeter and turns to Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, did you know that me and Mister Holbrook arranged for that bathroom? Sent the boys over and the equipment, too. Hilly stays on Aibileen, waiting for her to say something Skeeter fumes, hoping Aibileen doesn't say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am...And I thank you. Hilly smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...You. Are. Welcome. Hilly shoots Skeeter a last look. William Jr. leans into Hilly and hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One thing I got to say about Miss Hilly, she love her children. Always tellin' them they smart and beautiful. Can't go more than ten minutes without givin' one a kiss. Hilly kisses her son gently.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And, law, do they love her back. When she starts up on me, I just try and think a my sweet Treelore and how much he loved me. That kind a love makes me cry. Even when it going to Miss Hilly. Hilly again glances to the red satchel, staring quizzical at the worn booklet of The Jim Crow laws sticking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yule May washes dishes as the women are heard saying thei "good-byes" on the street. Skeeter slips into the kitchen 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I get you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yule May, I wanted to talk to you. Yule May turns off the sink faucet making sure Hilly is s cackling out on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you want to ask, Miss Skeeter. Aibileen and Minny already did. Yule May closes the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: YULE MAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm trying to get my boys off to college. It's worthwhile what y'all doing, but my boys are worth more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: What do you "understand," Skeeter? Skeeter and Yule May turn to find Hilly standing in the swinging door leading into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah...Yule May was just telling me how excited she was that her boys were going to go to college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true, Yule May?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am. Skeeter notices that Hilly is holding the booklet of Jim laws in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you also ask Miss Skeeter if you could borrow money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, Hilly! Hilly approaches Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, I'm starting to think you're intentionally not putting my initiative in the newsletter. Eyes down, Yule May hurries out of the kitchen. 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. I'm just so busy right now with Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter...I'm sorry about your mother. And I know you must be so worried. Hilly holds up the Jim Crow booklet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm worried about you. All this carrying on lately and now you're reading this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad had me get that for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, around your friends is one thing...But, believe it or not, there are real racists in this town! If the wrong person caught you with this...you'd be in serious trouble. Skeeter snatches the booklet from Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Hilly! And thanks for going through my things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter types feverishly while smoking a cigarette. Keys out: "Home Help Sanitation Initiative." Skeeter picks up Hilly's document and shakes her head. Sh types: Don't risk your children's and family's health!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yule May vacuums. She pulls the sofa away from the wall t clean beneath it. Noticing something on the floor, Yule May leans over. She rises holding a SMALL RUBY RING. Years of dust and ha blanket the pitiful gem set in ten karat gold. The vacuum seems to roar louder now. Yule May breathes heavily. She shoves the ring into her uniform pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Skeeter bangs away on her typewriter, Charlotte bursts into the room, stuck somewhere between panic and joy. 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't panic, but there's a very tall man named Stuart here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a drunken asshole, Mother. You wouldn't like him. Charlotte pulls a sun dress out of Skeeter's closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, love and hate are two horns on the same goat. And, you need a goat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, Charlotte and Stuart sit in the living room. Pascagoula serves finger sandwiches. Stuart looks nice in khaki pants, a blue blazer and a red tie. His nose is pink from working in the sun. No one says a word. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart, would you like a cocktail? Skeeter shoots her mother a "What the..." look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ma'am. Little too early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! Charlotte moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your last name, Stuart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whitworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm...Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natchez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Well, I know a Whitworth from Natchez...But he's a Senator up in Washington. 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am. That's my daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Whitworth. That's my father. Charlotte's jaw drops to her string of pearls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Stuart nods. Charlotte stands, flustered yet joyful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...tell him I said "Hello"...I'm going to go see if Pascagoula needs some help in the kitchen. Charlotte backs away behind Stuart's chair. She points at Skeeter violently, as if to say, DON'T MESS THIS UP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter and Stuart stand beneath an old Cypress tree as Charlotte peeps from an upstairs window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I know it was a few weeks back, but I came here to say I'm sorry for the way I acted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who sent you? William or Hilly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither. I was rude, and I've been thinking about it a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't. So, just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look. I told Hilly I wasn't ready to go out on any date. I wasn't even close to ready. Stuart shoves his hands in his pockets like a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was engaged last year. She ended it. Skeeter refuses to pity him. 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd been dating since we were fifteen. You know how it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I don't. I've never dated anyone before. Stuart looks up and starts laughing loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well! That must be it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never met a woman that said exactly what she was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got plenty to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to...come downtown with me and have dinner? We could talk... We could listen to each other this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think of anything worse. Stuart looks down and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, I'm sorry. That's what I came to say and...I said it. Stuart turns and walks towards his car, self-consciously weaving his strong fingers through his hair. Skeeter looks up to her mother's empty window and shouts to Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me a minute! Stuart turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get my sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter and Stuart sit closely as the same waiter as befo approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Skeeter? 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a Co-cola. Lots of ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean in life. What do you want? Only now does Skeeter notice the tray of champagne the wa is holding. Stuart nods as two glasses are set before the The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be a journalist. Maybe a novelist. Maybe both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that...I've been thinking about you. You're smart, you're pretty, you're...tall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And I read your column. Very informative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never knew Crisco got rid of diaper rash. Skeeter laughs and slaps him playfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you get to write something really good, Skeeter. Something you believe in. Stuart suddenly leans over and kisses Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart and Skeeter make out HARD in the back of the Holbrook's convertible. Hilly and William sit in the fron Hilly peers into the rearview mirror to get a better view Proud of herself, she pats William's leg. William slides his hand up Hilly's leg. She jerks it away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen sits on the kitchen floor next to a bucket. She feverishly scours grease off the baseboards. Elizabeth's car pulls up. Aibileen smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby girl home. 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car door slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Aibileen! My trunk's full! Aibileen rises slowly, placing a hand on her knee. Outsid Elizabeth suddenly shouts out hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Mae Mobley! No! Stop! Aibileen panics. She gets up, looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Mobley sits on Aibileen's toilet in the garage. Door wide open, pants around her ankles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Aibiee bafroom, Momma. Elizabeth runs over and yanks Mae Mobley off, popping her hard on the behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It! Is! Not! Mae Mobley begins to cry. Aibileen watches as Elizabeth h whispers and yanks Mae Mobley hard on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is dirty out here! You'll catch diseases. Elizabeth punctuates with three more slaps to her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen sits on the couch with Mae Mobley who eats a coo Mae Mobley's face is red and damp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, baby girl. Aibee's here. Aibileen kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You is kind. You is smart. You is important...You want me to tell you one a our secret stories? Mae Mobley nods. The phone rings. Aibileen rises.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: I got it! 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen sits back down and leans into Mae Mobley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day this wise Martian come down to Earth to teach us people a thing or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martian? How big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he about six-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martian Luther King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looked just like us, nose, mouth, hair on his head. But, sometimes people looked at him funny and were just downright mean to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Aibee? Why was they so mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Cause he was green. Elizabeth suddenly barges into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen! Come on! We have to go help Hilly. Now! Come on! Elizabeth runs outside. Aibileen grabs Mae Mobley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth wobbles briskly up the street holding her pregn belly. Aibileen and Mae Mobley follow. A stream of people walk toward them, laughing. They round a corner to see FIFTY OLD TOILETS, in every sh and color imaginable, littering Hilly's lawn. Some have towering tanks with chain pulls at the top, providing amusement to the procession of cars driving by. The Holbrook's station wagon sits in the driveway, doors still open with LUGGAGE tied to the roof. Two OLD BLACK MEN struggle to remove a toilet under Willi supervision. 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen hides her smile. Mae Mobley points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Look, Aibee. Hilly flies out of her house as a REPORTER snaps a pictur her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here! Hilly pushes him in the bushes and runs up to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter! She put it in the newsletter. I specifically said old coats are to be dropped at my house. Not commodes! Hilly faces the toilets again and screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She put it in the newsletter when she knew we'd be down at the beach. Hilly steps up to Aibileen and points to the old men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go help those boys GET THOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen rides in the back of a bus with a YOUNG BLACK MA Two white men sit right behind the white driver. The bus slows to a stop in the middle of the road. In the distance, blue lights flash in front of a road blo A few people gather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all stay put. Let me find out what's going on. As the driver gets up, a WLBT-TV news truck whizzes by followed by a police motorcycle. Aibileen leans in the ai and looks ahead. The driver returns. The young black man speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: What happen up there, Mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colored people off. White people lemme know where y'all are going. I'll get you as close as I can. 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the young black man helps Aibileen down the aisle, a w passenger taps the driver on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Aibileen and the young man walk down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Some nigger got shot. Where you headed? The bus door shuts and the driver backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen and the young man walk along a dark street. The sound of cicadas and sirens fill the air.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: You all right? You close to home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I be all right. My house is seven blocks from here.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: Want me to walk you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, thank ya. I'll be fine...Law, I hope this ain't as bad as- Aibileen turns to discover the young man is gone. She sta into the darkness. Scared, she begins to run. She cuts through a yard and trips over a hedge. She falls hard to her knees. Terrified, Aibileen begins to sob. She sees Minny's porch light and pulls herself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny sits with all five of her children, Sugar, LEROY JR 12, KINDRA, 10, FELICIA, 6, and BENNY, 4. They all listen anxiously to a radio on the table. Aibileen opens the screen door and falls to the floor. Minny jumps up to help her. She sees blood and grass stai streaking the knees of Aibileen's panty hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen! You okay? Aibileen nods, trying to compose herself. 81.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Almost ten years serving as the Field Secretary for the NAACP...Medgar Evers is dead. Aibileen swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KKK shot him! Hour ago. Right in front a his children, Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gone pray for the Evers. We gone pray for Myrlie. Minny raises her fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We living in hell! We trapped. Our kids is trapped. Minny turns to Sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your brother and sister and go get in my bed. Stay there! Sugar leads the kids to the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they gone do to us if they catch us with Miss Skeeter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gone be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch us to a pickup and drag us behind? Shoot me front a my kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't doing civil rights with Miss Skeeter. We just tellin' stories like they really happen. Minny and Aibileen grab hands and squeeze hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a fool, old woman. A fool! Aibileen hugs Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm on say this... But, I actually wish Leroy was home right now. Aibileen and Minny laugh a little through the tears. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine Stein sits at her desk flipping through the New Yo Times. She notices something, actually laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PAPER
dialogues.text: A picture shows Hilly standing among the fifty toilets in front yard. A caption reads: "Come on by, have a seat!" Home of William and Hilly Holbrook, Jackson, Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart, on the deck of an offshore oil rig, laughs as he looks at Hilly's picture inside a local newspaper. He writes on the back of a postcard addressed to Skeeter: I guess you potty trained Hilly! Much love, Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter parks and gets out of her car. She suddenly finds herself face to face with Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are sick. Do not speak to me. Do not look at me. Don't say hello to my children. How long had you been planning to humiliate my family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not it, Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought you were so clever, didn't ya? But I've already installed three of those old toilets in people's garages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technically, it was a typo, Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to tell Stuart he's ruining his reputation by associating with you. Jolene's yard boy saw you hanging around the colored bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't hanging- 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess your car was in the shop? Skeeter looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know as well as I do, people won't buy so much as a slice of pound cake from an organization that harbors racial integrationists! Skeeter steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, just who is that pound cake money being raised for, anyway? Hilly rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Starving Children of Africa." Skeeter nods and walks away. Hilly shouts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so you know, Lou Ann Templeton has taken your seat at bridge club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny walks in, notices it's eerily quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny walks into Celia's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia, you in here? Minny hears running water and muffled crying behind the bathroom door. She presses her ear to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? You sick? Minny twists the knob. It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Minny. Go on home for the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mess up your hair coloring again? I helped you fix it last time, got it back real pretty. 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia yells at Minny for the very first time.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: I said go home, Minny! Minny sees water creeping out from under the door. She st back and charges, shoulder first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom door bursts open with splinters of wood. Min slips in a pool of watered down blood. Celia sits against the wall in a bloody nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Celia! Celia aimlessly moves the blood around with a wash cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's so much blood. Why is there so much blood this time? Minny crawls over, peers into the toilet bowl and gags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Minny. Will you get it out? I can't look at it again. Shaken, Minny reaches for a trash can. She puts her hand Celia's neck and pushes it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your head down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia lies in bed while Minny presses a cool rag to her forehead. Celia stares out of her bedroom window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two rosebushes stand in the middle of the front lawn. A DOCTOR enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her another pill if she gets too agitated. There'll be more bleeding, but don't call me unless it's heavy. Minny nods as the doctor leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got married because I was pregnant. But it slipped out too. 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just God's way. Next one's gonna catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny wants kids now. I thought if I was real still, brought somebody in to do the house and cooking, maybe I'd hold on to this one. Oh, Minny, what's he gonna do with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gone have to get over this. He needs to know this takes time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know about this one, or the one before... Minny turns to Celia, stunned by this revelation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny, you know how to play bridge, don't you? Minny nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. I used to help Missus Walters practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen holds a plate of grits covered in toasted marshmallows, strawberries and three lighted candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday! Mae Mobley two today! Mae Mobley laughs as Aibileen sets down the grits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Mobley three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure is, Baby Girl. Blow'em out `fo they run up in your grits. Mae Mobley blows out the candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you, Aibiee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you get burfdays? 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Mobley picks up a candle and licks off the grits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone be fifty-four next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have some babies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gots seventeen of `em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the babies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all over town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibee...You're my real mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you know who your momma is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your real baby, Aibee. Those other ones are just pretend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia digs a hole next to the two existing rosebushes. A closed shoebox and new rosebush wait to be planted. Celia lowers the box in the grave, covering it with dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia and Minny sit at a card table holding playing cards Two additional hands lay face up on the table in front of empty chairs across from them. Minny lays down one of her cards then looks over to Celia hand. She removes a card from Celia's and lays it down. She the points to the hand next to Celia. Celia nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly stands at her podium, tan and ready to lead. She ho her gavel like a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. First order of business. We're updating our newsletter. Hilly stares right at Skeeter who sits alone in the back. 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're adding a fashion column with all the latest trends...Your dresses better be cute at next week's benefit! The women applaud and tap each other on their thighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's time to choose a new editor for our new modern monthly. Skeeter braces herself as hands pop up everywhere. Jolene French stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I nominate Hilly Holbrook. Jolene looks back and snarls at Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jolene, you're the sweetest thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I second. I third. All in favor of Hilly, say "Aye." The room erupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye! Skeeter's ousting took less than ten seconds. Elizabeth secretly turns to Skeeter from a few rows ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits alone on the porch swing in her nightgown, shifting through the Miss Myrna letters. Charlotte steps onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, would you like me to drop you off at bridge club on the way to my doctor's appointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ma'am. It's been cancelled. Mae Mobley's sick or something. 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridge is underway at the Leefolt house. Aibileen enters holding a tray of coffee cups. Elizabeth, Hilly, Jolene and several other girls giggle a they kneel down behind furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay? Elizabeth looks back. Her belly is huge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh! There's a knock at door.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, it's me, Celia Foote. I was in the neighborhood and thought I'd drop by. The girls giggle more loudly now. Celia peers into the living room window. The bridge tables are in plain view. Celia's face grows pinker than her sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...brought you a chocolate pie...My maid, Minny, made it. Hilly's face hardens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny stands at the sink shelling peas. A distinct red cu is perched above her swollen eye. Celia sits at the kitchen table halfway through the pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They made me stand there like the vacuum man. Why, Minny? Minny freezes, keeping her face on the peas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they know about you getting knocked up by Mister Johnny. They mad you married one a they mens. Especially since Mister Johnny and Miss Hilly had just broke up, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Hilly probably thinks I was fooling around with Johnny while they were still going steady. 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missus Walters says Miss Hilly still sweet on Mister Johnny, too. Celia suddenly slaps her thigh with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder! They don't hate me...They hate what they think I did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hate you cause they think you're white trash! And don't be takin' pies to those women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just going to have to let Hilly know I'm not a boyfriend stealer. In fact, I'll tell her Friday night at the benefit. Celia rises and smiles like she just cured cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Miss Celia...please don't be going to that benefit. Celia gets some ice out of the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said? Celia places the ice in a towel and approaches Minny. She looks at the cut above her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That looks bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to get my work done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you didn't fall in the tub, Minny. Let me take a look. Celia grabs Minny's hand. Minny pulls away. Just then Johnny pulls up in the driveway. Celia and Minn turn to the window, then spring into action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny sits crouched on the lid of the guest bath toilet a Johnny chases Celia around the house. Celia giggles. 90.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Come here, Sexy!

dialogues.speaker: CELIA, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Johnny, you are bad! Bad! Bad! Minny looks at the ridiculous image of herself crouching the toilet in the bathroom mirror. She raises Celia's ice rag up to her swollen eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter enters quietly through Aibileen's kitchen door. She is surprised to see twenty other black women standing solemnly around the kitchen and the living room. Aibileen approaches with a worried look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yule May in prison, Miss Skeeter. Gone be there four years. Minny shouts out across the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly Holbrook been sent from the devil to ruirn all our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly and the usual suspects play bridge at Hilly's house Aibileen pours coffee an earshot away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! A nigra walks in a pawn shop with a ring of such size and clarity. It took'em all of five minutes to figure out where she worked. Hilly leads the girls' nods of acknowledgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that girl was a thief the day she started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Minny wipes her nose with her sleeve, Skeeter approach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll ask daddy to get her a good lawyer. 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had a lawyer. A white lawyer! But Miss Hilly friends with the judge's wife. Whole thing took two days. Arrested on Tuesday, in the state pen by Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church gone send them boys to college. Gone pass the plate `til they graduate... The women part, making way as Aibileen leads Skeeter to a seat at the kitchen table. PEARLY, 58, sits next to Skeeter and touches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on help with your stories. Another WOMAN walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on help too. Another woman speaks from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all are. Women of all ages slowly rise up and nod their heads. Ske looks around in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I don't know what to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They doing this for Yule May.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits and writes as Pearly begins the interviews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been there thirty-eight years and Miss Margaret still makes me put my hair up in a rag. Say she know coloreds don't wash theys hair. But, I love her. She love me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had been workin' for Miss Jolene's mother up `til she died. Then her daughter, Miss Nancy, asked me to come work for her. Miss Nancy a real sweet lady. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But her momma left it in the will that I had to work for her daughter, Miss Jolene. Miss Jolene a mean woman. Mean for sport. I tried to get another job, but in everbody mind, the French family and Miss Jolene owned me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CALLIE, 60, takes off her glasses and wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to take a shortcut ever day to work at Doctor Dixon's house. Cut through this farmer's lower forty to get there. One day, that farmer was waitin' on me with a gun, said he'd shoot me dead if I walk on his land again. Doctor Dixon went and paid that farmer double for two a those acres. Told him he `bout to start farmin' too. But he bought it just for me. So I could get to work easy. He did. Skeeter closes her eyes for moment. When she opens them she sees A VISION OF CONSTANTINE STAN BEFORE HER. Constantine smiles and grabs Skeeter's hand. She presses thumb firmly in her palm. When Skeeter blinks again, the vision is gone. Standing in place of Constantine is GRETCHEN, 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All these colored women have been real nice, haven't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they hate you. You know this? Every little thing about you. But you're so dumb, you think you're doing them a favor. Skeeter and the other maids are taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the nicest thing a white woman's ever done for me? Gave me the heel of her bread. These women are playing a trick on you. They'll never tell you the truth! 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what they've said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it, lady, say the word you think every time one us stands in front of you. Nigger. Aibileen crosses over to Gretchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Gretchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just as dumb as she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out a my house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen sits with Skeeter on the sofa reading and answer Miss Myrna letters. Aibileen is dressed very nicely. Several flower arrangements are placed around the room. A unwrapped present rests on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her to pour vinegar in her trash cans. Then them dogs will stay away. As Skeeter writes this down, someone walks onto Aibileen' front porch. Skeeter becomes worried. Aibileen looks to a wall clock and smiles. About a dozen letters and cards fall into a basket under mail slot. Aibileen jumps up and starts sorting through the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today my birthday, Miss Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, happy birthday, Aibileen. You should have told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, from all over the county, my babies find they way home. Aibileen stops on one card in particular. She sits back d next to Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some even from overseas. Alton Spears lives in Paris now. Married him a real pretty French girl. Got five kids, too...they's my grandbabies. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen opens the card to find a twenty dollar bill insi along with a picture of the Spears family. Aibileen reads the card aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't drink coffee. Happy Birthday. Love Alton. Aibileen laughs and raises her hand to her mouth. Skeeter touched. The doorbell rings. Aibileen jumps up and opens the door. delivery man greets her with two more vases of flowers. Aibileen looks out to the street where a white woman gets of her car with a huge country ham. Two little girls in matching dresses jump out behind her. The woman sees Aibileen on the porch and waves. Aibileen waves back and smiles. Catching it all, the moment soon grows bittersweet for Skeeter. She wipes her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning light shines into Skeeter's room. Stuart has returned from the rig. Fully clothed, he and Skeeter slee on Skeeter's bed. Charlotte shouts Skeeter's name from down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Eugenia?! Skeeter's eyes pop open. She's groggy and hasn't fully realized the company lying next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Stuart throws his arm over Skeeter. Reality sinks in. Skeeter rolls over to find Stuart, eyes shut, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Oh my God! When Stuart tries to get up, Skeeter flattens him reaches down and pulls the covers up over his entire body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move a muscle! Skeeter props up on her side and faces the door making su the covers hide that she's clothed. Charlotte enters and heads straight for Skeeter's closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Sleepy Head. 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Mom. Charlotte pulls out a dress and lays it on the bed, right top of Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you could take me to the doctor this morning and then we could get some lunch afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure! Charlotte spies a LARGE TOE sticking out of the covers. I belongs to Stuart, but she assumes it's Skeeter's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at toe) Or...we could...go straight to Fanny Mae's for a girl day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! I'll get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did Stuart leave last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right after you went to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope he knows he's welcome to stay in Carlton's old room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really ready for that yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bird in the hand," Eugenia. Bird. In. The. Hand... Charlotte exits and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under the covers.) Chirp. Chirp. Skeeter is mortified. Stuart sits up, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Stuart tries to kiss Skeeter. She resists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My breath is horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is mine. 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart embraces Skeeter and brings his lips close to hers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bank's clock shows twelve noon in downtown Jackson. It' eerily quiet, not a soul on the street... We hear archival footage of Walter Cronkite addressing th nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny stands at the top of a tall step ladder vacuuming Oscar's head. Celia runs into the living room. Tears stream down her fa Minny turns to Celia. Cronkite tells the nation that John F. Kennedy is dead. Minny's eyes roll back in her head as she starts to faint She grabs on to Oscar's body and slides down to the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly sits with her son William playing on a blanket on t front lawn. A neighbor suddenly pulls up in his car stopping in front Hilly. He leans out and tells Hilly the tragic news. In complete disbelief, Hilly puts her hand over her mouth She then grabs William, pulls him in close as if he's som in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen huddles with a dozen other maids in a circle. They're all crying. Some throw their hands in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter and Stuart sit solemnly with the Phelan family watching Cronkite's coverage of the Kennedy funeral. Skeeter's dad wipes tears from his eyes. Stuart checks th time and leans into Skeeter's ear. 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm sorry, but I have to get down to the coast. Skeeter nods as Stuart kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back in time for the benefit. Love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, too. We hear Walter Cronkite's parting thoughts on JFK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny, Skeeter and Aibileen sit quietly compiling stories Aibileen and Minny look up to Aibileen's framed picture o John F. Kennedy. Aibileen grows anxious. She suddenly jumps out of her cha and paces around the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world done gone crazy, Miss Skeeter! And I'm scared! What if folks find out what we writing? Figure out Niceville really Jackson, and figure out who who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen. We've changed all the names. Aibileen snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all two gone sit there and tell me you one hundred percent without a doubt sure `bout all this?! Skeeter looks away..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...So I been thinking...Maybe we need us some insurance. Skeeter look to Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told God I'd never speak of it again. But we got no choice. It's time...Time to tell you both "the terrible awful" I did to Miss Hilly. It might be the only thing to protect us. 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We continue with the earlier flashback where Minny arrive Hilly's with her famed chocolate pie. Hilly leads Minny i the kitchen, Missus Walters follows behind. Hilly slices a big piece and grabs a fork. She leans agai the counter and takes a big bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody wanted to hire a sass- mouthing, thieving nigra, did they? Minny stands silent as Hilly finishes in three bites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pie's as good as always, Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you like it. Hilly cuts another piece for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If...I take you back, I'll have to cut your pay five dollars a week. Not expecting this, Minny leans away from Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me back? Hilly takes an even bigger bite from the second slice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you put in here that makes it taste so good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That good vanilla from Mexico... Minny's eyes narrow over a forced smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...something else real special. Missus Walters grabs a plate and reaches for the pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Missus Walters. That Miss Hilly's special pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma can have a piece. Hilly slides the pie a little too fast down the counter toward Minny. Minny stops it before it falls to the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut her one. 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat my shit. Hilly calmly sets her plate down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said eat my shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you lost your mind?! Minny moves toward Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But you're about to, `cause you just did. Minny nods smugly as she looks down at Hilly's slice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did what? Missus Walters immediately gets it. She bursts out laughi so hard she has to lower herself to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Hilly, that's what you get, I guess. And you didn't just eat one. You ate two slices! Hilly starts to hyperventilate as everything sinks in. As Minny leaves, Hilly runs to the sink and throws up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen and Skeeter are speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trying to get yourself killed?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I never planned to tell her! I just wanted to see her take a bite and leave so I could be done with her. Forever! She was never supposed to ask me back. Minny eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, then for less pay! That got me even madder. And, then she went slid that pie at me. Oh lord! That was it! I just lost control, Aibileen...you know how I get, now. 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, before I knew it, it just came on out my mouth...and I had tolt her what was in that pie. Aibileen looks to Skeeter shaking her head. Minny suddenl gets misty. She wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked God to forgive me. But, more for what happened to poor Missus Walters. Miss Hilly threw her in that nursing home just for laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't put that story in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too dangerous, Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need insurance! Hilly Holbrook can't never let people know that pie story is about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! If people find out "The Terrible Awful" was you and Miss Hilly, then we in trouble. Trouble there ain't words for!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! But don't you see? Miss Hilly gone go to her grave convincing people this book ain't about Jackson. Then we safe, insured! Minny gets up and walks toward Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought me into this, and I'm on finish it! Either put it in or pull my parts out all together. Minny storms out of Aibileen's kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Stein talks to Skeeter on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last editor's meeting is December 17th. If you want a chance of this getting read, I need it in my hands by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's in a week, Miss Stein! 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise it goes in The Pile. You don't want it in The Pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you must get a piece in about the domestic who raised you. It'll add something personal to it. Skeeter nods with frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The African Children's Benefit Ball is well underway. The energy and look of the two hundred attendees feel lik throwback to the women's suffrage movement. Many older wo wear heavy long black skirts and jackets. Hilly wears swathes of maroon-colored taffeta. Ruffles clutch her throat. She stands next to Jolene French and a WLBT CAMERAMAN. Dressed to the nines, Jolene raises a microphone and look into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jolene French reporting from the African Children's Benefit Ball, and I'm here with League President Miss Hilly Holbrook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jolene... Three dozen servers stand in a line. Minny and Aibileen a among them. Tables are covered with items donated for the auction. On the baked goods table, Minny's famed chocolate pie promises to again be a big money maker. Celia and Johnny enter the ballroom. Celia wears a hideou pink and silver sequined gown. As usual, Celia's breasts command attention. The room locks on Celia as specks of light bounce off her dress and jiggle across the ceiling. A TITILLATED OLD HUSBAND tips his martini onto his wife's shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little too loudly) Look at the jugs on that one! 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other wives dig fingernails into husbands' arms. The man' wife responds louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bosoms are for bedrooms and breast- feeding. Not occasions of dignity. Celia downs a glass of champagne and leans into Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I might have overdressed a little? It's supposed to be formal, but this looks like a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look gorgeous. Minny pulls Aibileen aside and points to Celia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what she got on. Celia grabs more champagne from a passing server.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy. Ladies better hold onto they husbands tonight. Celia catches eyes with Minny. She smiles and nods quickl and then looks away, careful not to tip off Johnny of the relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the man that don't even know he's paying me. Skeeter enters with Stuart. She wears a long-sleeved blac velvet dress and her hair is being somewhat cooperative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Skeeter and that must be Stuart. He's handsome... Missus Walters?! Missus Walters enters wearing a floor-length blue beaded gown, circa 1943. A white orchid wilts at her clavicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly can throw her in a home, but she can't keep the taxis away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia approaches Elizabeth and Jolene who talk next to a punch bowl. Celia is now drinking some kind of pink drink with an umbrella sticking out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello, Elizabeth. 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Elizabeth's homemade maternity ball gown resembles a velv potato sack cinched with red ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are lovely dresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?! I was worried I was a tad overdressed. Jolene reaches out an pats Celia's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. You're just perfect. Elizabeth pulls Jolene away. Celia downs her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests are now seated at twenty-eight round tables. Scores of black servers dressed in tuxedos ferry plates. Hilly makes her way to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody enjoying their dinner? The room claps enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's give a nice round of applause for all the men and women that have helped make tonight possible. Hilly mechanically gestures toward the servers in the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cause I'm sure is dear to their hearts as well. Skeeter shakes her head as the less inspired applause die down. Celia waves to Minny and jumps out of her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woo-hoo! Johnny grabs Celia by the arm and pulls her back down. Ce reaches for Johnny's glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, maybe you've had enough to drink. Try to eat your dinner. 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And have my stomach poke out?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Celia looks at the prize table's bids, Johnny and Stua lean against a bar chatting with a few other bored men. Hilly suddenly slides next to Johnny completely ignoring Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Johnny Foote. I'm surprised to see you here. Everybody knows you can't stand parties like this. Hilly squeezes the crook of his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia wouldn't have missed this for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is that wife of yours? Out selling hotdogs? Johnny looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know I'm teasing you. We dated long enough where I can do that, can't I? Johnny walks away leaving Hilly no choice but to acknowle Stuart. She and Stuart never look each other's way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly. Hilly walks away as Jolene approaches the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the list of winners!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jolene finishes up the winners list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you enjoy your new set of tires, Missus Atwell. Now, on to the baked goods. Jolene flips a page. 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yum! Yum! The highest bid in baked goods goes to Minny Jackson's chocolate pie. Congratulations, Hilly Holbrook! The room erupts in applause. Hilly now sits at a table wi her family, Missus Walters, and the Leefolts. Skeeter and Stuart sit at a table full of elderly people don't know. Minny clears dishes nearby. Hearing her name, she becomes very alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I didn't bid on anything. Minny turns to find Hilly smiling at her tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, wasn't that sweet. Someone signed me up for that pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Celia rushes up behind Hilly, her voice slurred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
