dialogues.text: Congratulations, Hilly! I didn't know you're a fan of Minny's pies. Hilly remains calm. Celia grabs Hilly's long sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've wanted to talk to you all night. Minny told me why you won't be my friend. You think me and Johnny went behind your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go! Hilly stands up and pulls away. A ripping sound cuts thro the air. Celia stares at Hilly's torn cuff in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to do to me? What are you and that nigra up to? 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jolene announces another round of winners loudly over the microphone, forcing Celia to raise her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -You liar! Who did you tell?! Jolene loses her place on the list. The room grows quiet Celia is still yelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, I got pregnant after you and Johnny broke up! The room echoes with Celia's words. Across the room, wome noses wrinkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Mother. Stuart belts out with a laugh. Skeeter pinches his arm. Celia is mortified. Sweat beads on her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny never cheated on you...At least, not with me. Celia starts to breathe heavily. Her eyes start to water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny would never-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm sorry I thought you'd be tickled to win that pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell that nigra if she tells anybody, I will make her suffer. Horrified, Skeeter catches eyes with Minny and Aibileen. They all immediately look away. Johnny makes his way over. Celia holds her breath, shakin her head back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia, what's wrong, Honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Celia leans over and vomits on the fleur-de-lis print car The entire room gasps in horror. 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit! Johnny tries to pull Celia back. She pushes Johnny away a runs for the bathroom. He follows. Hilly marches over to Aibileen who is standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that cleaned up before it starts to smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny's daughter, Sugar, stands over a large commercial s filled with sudsy water, washing dishes. Minny approaches from behind as Sugar holds court with fi other young girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That big-boobed lady Momma works for was drunker than an Injun on payday. Upchucked in front a everbody! As the girls all laugh, Minny pops Sugar hard on the back her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you never let me hear you talking bad about the lady who puts food in your mouth. Clothes on your back! You hear me? Minny storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do it all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly and William walk to their car. Missus Walters follo closely behind, holding Minny's pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just come on home and stay with us tonight, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I got a pie to eat. Hilly spins around and sees the pie. 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You throw that pie away right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent good money on this. Won it just for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?! You signed me up? Missus Walters steps up to Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may have trouble remembering my own name and what country I live in. But there's two things I can't seem to forget. That my own daughter threw me in a nursing home...And that she ate Minny's shit. Missus Walters winks at Hilly and ambles to a waiting tax cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia lies in bed with the covers pulled over her face. Minny enters carrying a tray of food, setting it down nex two other trays of uneaten food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't Mister Johnny gone wonder how dinner got on the table if you laid up in bed? Celia pulls the covers off her head and sits up a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way Hilly looked at me. Like I was trash on the road. Celia pulls a letter out from under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She billed me for her dress. In lieu of payment, she's asked that I send two-hundred dollars to the African Children's Fund and then she banned me from all future League events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't count. Don't judge yourself by the way she see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not right for this kind of life, Minny. I don't need a dinner table for twelve people. 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't get two people over here if I begged. She called me a liar and accused me of getting her that pie. I wouldn't have thrown up if it wasn't for that! I can't do this anymore to Johnny. I'm going back to Sugar Ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gone leave your husband cause you threw up at some party? Celia sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, I reckon it's time you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia stares at Minny, wide-eyed and disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Hilly thought you knew `bout "The Terrible Awful," that you were making fun a her. It's my fault she pounced on you. But if you leave Mister Johnny, then Miss Hilly done won the whole ball game. Then she done beat me, and she done beat you. Celia lies there. Minny's concerned she's said too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. For telling me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart lies on a bed inside the Presidential Suite of the Roosevelt Hotel. He's on the phone with Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter talks to Stuart. Pascagoula cooks breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart! How are you calling me? Aren't you on the rig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I told you I have twenty- four hours in New Orleans? 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I'm in the Presidential Suite of the Roosevelt Hotel...That we have dinner reservations in the Blue Room tonight and lunch tomorrow at Galatoires. Skeeter becomes troubled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? I spoke to your dad, and he's gonna have Jameso drive you down right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work in the car. Jesus, Skeeter, it's a cleaning column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a deadline, Sweetie. You should have asked me about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to be romantic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Honey. I can't come. Stuart shakes his head and hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen and Skeeter sit across from, FAYE BELLE, 101, palsied and gray skinned and hunched in a wheelchair. Aibileen grabs Faye Belle's hand stirring a sudden flash memory. Her voice is coarse and hard to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember hiding with Miss Lilia in a steamer trunk while Yankee soldiers stomped through Master's house. We were both four. Eighty- five years later she died in my arms. We's were friends `til the end. Her grandson still pays my rent. Buys all my groceries too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manuscript sits before Aibileen, Minny and Skeeter. 111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have one more story to type, but other than that, we are done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law, look at all them pages. Two- hundred and sixty-six of `em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we just wait and see? Hopin' Missus Stein publish it? Skeeter nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What story you got left to type?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine. Aibileen looks at Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your momma won't tell you, I reckon I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red-eyed, Skeeter enters Charlotte's room. A bowl rests o the bedside table with a wet rag draped over the side. Charlotte is wig free and terribly thin. Her collarbone protrudes long and narrow, but her eyes are as sharp as e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been crying? You know that ages your skin, Dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, I need to talk to you about Constantine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Eugenia. That was so long ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have to speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you look. I was good to Constantine. Oh, she talked back plenty of times, and I put up with it. But, Skeeter, she didn't give me a choice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...happened? 112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte, much healthier, scurries around the house adjusting flower arrangements and straightening pictures.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was hosting a D.A.R. luncheon. Constantine was to do the floors that morning so they'd be dry in time. Charlotte finds Constantine mopping the foyer very slowly The effects of arthritis are apparent.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, the floors were soaking wet when the first guest arrived. A guest unnecessarily grabs a table for balance, making a point about the damp floor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte sits with twelve women at the dining table as Constantine pushes the casserole cart around and begins serving lunch. As the guests sip coffee, each woman grimaces and turns t Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then, she burned the coffee. She had gotten so old, Skeeter. Charlotte shoots Constantine a look. Constantine nods sorrowfully. She picks up a woman's plate and begins fill it with food from the cart very slowly. Constantine strains to lower the plate in front of the wo Her hands tremble.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her mishaps were becoming a daily occurrence, and I had had it. The plate tilts causing peas to pour into the woman's lap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out! With that, Charlotte stands up and slaps the table with h hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a hold of yourself, Constantine! Constantine slowly looks to Charlotte. Totally exhausted, she grips the casserole cart with both hands to steady herself. 113.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that's when it happened. Constantine wets herself. Slowly the women begin realizing what's happening. The tw women closest to Constantine gasp and quickly move away f her. Another woman rises from the table covering her mouth wit napkin and leaves the room. Just now realizing what has happened, Constantine looks d at her soiled dress. No one says a word. No one comes to Constantine's aid. Constantine looks to Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constantine hobbles with a cane down a gravel road still wearing her soiled dress. She turns and looks one last ti at the Phelan Plantation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her she couldn't work here anymore and to go on home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter trembles. Charlotte won't look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you humiliate her like that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you help her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was upset. I didn't know what else to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you just threw her away? That woman did you the biggest favor of your life. She taught me kindness and self respect and you just threw her away like a broken appliance. Charlotte starts to cry. Skeeter isn't affected. 114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't throw her away, Skeeter. Your daddy went to her house the very next day to give her her job back. But she had already moved to Chicago. Left everything behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Cause she didn't have anything anymore. You broke her heart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't do this to me, Skeeter. I feel terrible. And you have to remember, they're not like us. They are different. Charlotte gets defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you idolized her too much! You always have!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed somebody to look up to. Skeeter turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go find her. She needs me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finally found the address of her daughter in Chicago...so we sent Carlton up there to go get Constantine. Skeeter turns back to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he got there...she was dead, Eugenia. I'm so sorry, Honey. Charlotte tries to comfort her. Skeeter rejects her mothe hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't y'all tell me all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd blame me...when it wasn't my fault. It just happened, and it was so unfortunate. I'm sorry, Eugenia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did she die? How long had she been in Chicago? 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte pulls the white basin closer, hugs it to her si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks. Skeeter stands, never turning as she exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter stands on the back patio crying. She slowly walks off into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Constantine's story finally made it in our book. But the reason she got fired did not. Miss Skeeter just couldn't put that kind a shame on her own mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front window of a bookstore displays many of the nati top selling books. A clerk sets a tiny stack of books in the far corner.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They printed a few thousand copies with the worst advance Miss Stein had ever seen. The stack is "The Help," in hardcover. It's wrapped in pa blue. A white peace dove spreads its wing under the title

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny stands over the stove frying chicken as Sugar enter with the day's mail. Minny snatches the mail from her and sees an envelope from Harper and Row. Minny tears it open. Her eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We got four hundred dollars. Got another four hundred when it got printed. Divided thirteen ways that came to sixty-one fifty-three a person. Minny hugs Sugar and runs out the screen door with her ch as the chicken sizzles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen and Minny hug each other as the jump up and down with checks in hand. 116.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Minny got so excited she burnt up a skillet of chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny knocks on the door holding bags of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Miss Celia! Get out a that bed and let me in. It's twelve noon. I did all the shopping just like you asked. The door slowly opens. Celia steps out onto the porch, looking beautiful, still dressed tacky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at you, Miss Celia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia leads Minny into the dining room. The table, set beautifully in silver and crystal, is covered with delici looking casseroles and fried chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cooked it all by myself. I wanted to do something special. I wanted to say "thank you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia and Minny dine, and Minny's enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greens got just the right amount a hock taste to `em. That's a good pot liquor, Miss Celia. Who taught you to cook like this? Minny winks as she dunks a piece of corn bread in the gre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corn bread's happy now. Celia lays down her fork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you happy, Minny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you ask such a funny question? 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A course I's happy. You happy too. Big house, big yard, good husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, if I were you, I'd give it right back to him. I'd hit him over the head with a skillet and tell him to go straight to hell... Minny starts to protest but is tired of excuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I will. Celia jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost forgot the dessert. Minny smiles softly as Celia disappears into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen irons as Elizabeth enters with shopping bags. She races to the television and turns it on. As the tube warms up, we hear the conclusion of a Tide commercial. WLBT's lunchtime show, "People Will Talk," continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jolene French sits on the set of Jackson's morning show. MALE HOST watches as the show runner counts down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five, four, three, two, one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back to "People Will Talk." And do we have something to talk about. Jolene has quite a book to review. Jolene shakes her head, visibly upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly watches Jolene on television as her new maid, ERNESTINE, pours a cup of coffee with her right hand. 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernestine's left arm is missing. The maid pickings for Hi have gotten slim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you frowning, Jolene? Hilly leans over and taps her television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look cute that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called "The Help." A new book by an anonymous author. Aibileen jerks her head toward the television.

dialogues.speaker: MALE HOST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Touching and enlightening, it's filled with testimonials from Mississippi's own housekeepers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny watches transfixed as she and Celia eat dessert in front of the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look how cute that dress is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes place in the fictional town of "Niceville." The book is dedicated to C and T. If you're out there C and T, we'd love to have you on the show because Niceville sounds like Jackson, if you ask me. The host starts laughing. Jolene snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Jackson! It's a disgrace to the South! A disgrace to good Southern women who've spent their lives taking care of their help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke rises from the shirt Aibileen is ironing. She snaps attention, pulls the iron off the burned shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But did you read that ending?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I personally treat my help like family, and every one of my friends does the same. 119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha, if you're listening, I have a new found respect for what you do. And, believe me, I'll be passin' on dessert at your table!

dialogues.speaker: FOOTE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Minny walks like a zombie over to Celia and gathers her d plate, never taking her eyes off the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not buy this book! Ladies of Jackson, do not support slander with your husband's hard earned- Poof! Jolene disappears by way of a Seal-Lily ice cream commercial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cut her off like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that book called, Aibileen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I wasn't paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacks of "The Help" rest on tables in the store. Elizabeth enters, pick up two copies and pulls them close her body. She races to the register like a teen buying a Playboy.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE PHOTOGRAPHY
dialogues.text: Back at the table of books, we see in rapid succession th books quickly disappearing by the hands of Jacksonians.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Aibileen, Skeeter and Minny sit at the table. Aibileen's phone rings off the wall, but she won't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew nothing about it. Miss Stein's P.R. Department called the station directly. 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever maid callin' to say they white lady's gone and bought the book. They so scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `One-arm-Earnestine' said Miss Leefolt brought a copy over to Miss Hilly in less than a hour. She better read it quick and start the "this ain't Jackson crusade."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't count on it. In her one year at Ole Miss she never cracked a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she gone read it. Especially after that man made such a stink on the tee-vee. She gone read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Hilly read the book aloud over the phone wi each other. They stop and nod with speculation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus is filled with domestics en route to work. Everyone either reading the book or having it read to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missus Walters reads to a group of women in the home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte lies in bed reading the book next to Robert, wh asleep. As she turns a page, her face reveals a dawning realizati Troubled, she starts to wake Robert but doesn't. Charlotte trembles as she brings the book in close to her chest. She slides down to her pillow and stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits on the swing with Stuart who's just arrived the rig, still wearing his dingy work clothes. 121.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That month felt like a year. I missed you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, I told Daddy I'm not going back on the rig. Stuart nonchalantly pulls out a ring from his front pocke and places it in Skeeter's lap. A huge diamond is surrounded by twelve small sapphires. Skeeter's smile quickly fades as she raises the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart...I have to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about "yes?!" I had this with me down in New Orleans, you know. Skeeter touches Stuart's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious...and...you have to promise not to tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on. Did you say `yes'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Stuart hugs Skeeter. She pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But listen. Can I have your word? Skeeter has again ruined Stuart's big moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. You have my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart storms off the porch, dumbfounded. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what you've been writing for the last twelve months?! What happened to the cleaning column?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did both. 122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter approaches Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the talk in town? I said they were dead wrong. Told them you were too smart to get mixed up in anything like that. Skeeter reaches to calm him. He pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That joke you played on Hilly with the toilets. Hell, that's funny. But this? I don't understand why you did this...why you even care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are fine around here. Why stir up trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not stirring up trouble, Stuart. Trouble's already here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it is. Skeeter grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to tell you. You needed to know. Stuart shakes his head and pulls away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I don't really know you, Skeeter. And I can't marry somebody I don't know. Stuart looks down at the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my grandmother's. Skeeter hands the ring back. Stuart shoves it in his pock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I won't tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte sits in bed next to Robert who is fast asleep. hears a door closing outside. 123.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter?! Come in here, please. After a few moments, Skeeter enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? Can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Eugenia. I want to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart proposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. He had to ask Daddy for your hand. She lifts Skeeter's ring hand. Seeing her bare finger, Charlotte's smile fades. Skeeter prepares for the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! Skeeter stands to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young lady, I'm talking to you! Skeeter sits back down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart'll come around. It's a funny dance. (points to Robert ) Took this one a year. Anyway, my news. After a long talk with your daddy, I've made a decision. My health's been on the uptick these past few weeks. And I know the doctor says it's some kind of last

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte starts coughing. Skeeter hands her a tissue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, as I said, I made a decision. I have decided not to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Momma. Charlotte slaps her palms as if throwing the cancer away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. I tried calling Fanny Mae's so I could make your hair appointments for the next twenty years, but they wouldn't allow it. Charlotte raises Skeeter's ring finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I certainly can't leave you now. Skeeter laughs and hugs her mother. Robert never stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly drives in front of Jitney Jingle grocery store. She wears a scarf on her head and big sunglasses. One-armed Ernestine rides in the passenger seat. Hilly slows in front of the store's big glass entrance. S hurriedly waves Ernestine out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The voters of Hinds County had spoke. Mister Holbrook wasn't gone have no political career. One-Arm Ernestine races to the storefront and removes William's campaign poster taped to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly reads the book in bed. William is fast asleep. Suddenly, her eyes widen, her breath becomes heavy. She slowly turns a page and freezes. Her face turns white. Hilly balls both fists, looks to the ceiling and screams louder than humanly possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter lies in bed sleeping. Her eyes pop open. 125.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen lies in bed sleeping. Her eyes pop open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny lies in bed sleeping. Her eyes pop open. But, this time, Hilly's scream fades as knocks at the door grow lou Knocking that has actually stirred Minny awake. Sugar and Kindra enter, jumping in bed with Minny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma, there's a white man at our door!

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Minny Jackson! Are you in there?! Minny covers the girls with a blanket. She puts on a robe grabs a bat from behind the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: I can hear you. Open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny approaches the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Foote. Minny Jackson, I want to talk to you. Open up. Minny slowly opens the door. Johnny is all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, I meet Minny Jackson... As Johnny enters, Minny raises the bat and swings. Johnny turns and stops the bat with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doin'?! Minny lets go of the bat and cowers on the floor, raises hands in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't hurt me! My babies are in the house. Johnny drops the bat and pulls Minny up from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, girl. I'm not here to get you. 126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly throws his arms around her and squeezes hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny and Minny sit at her kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I finally confronted Celia about you, she told me about the baby. All of them. You saved her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know the day you came to our house, she started getting better. And I'm not just talking about the cookin' either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew I was there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fried chicken and okra on the first night? Y'all should have at least put corn pone on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't make you eat anymore corn pone, Mister Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning, I snuck back up to the house, peeked in the window, and there you were. Given ol' Oscar a wipe down. Minny smiles for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I ain't losing my job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a job with us for the rest of your life, if you want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridge is underway at the Leefolt house with the usual suspects, except Skeeter. LOU ANN TEMPLETON has taken her place. Aibileen nervously pours coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard that Betty character might be Charlene. 127.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Jackson, and that book is garbage. I bet the whole thing's made up by some nigra. Aibileen begins pouring coffee into Hilly's cup.

dialogues.speaker: LOU ANN TEMPLETON
dialogues.text: And, Jolene, didn't your momma leave Cora to you in her will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes...But that's not odd is it? Happens all the time, right? A sudden realization washes over Jolene.

dialogues.speaker: LOU ANN TEMPLETON
dialogues.text: Did anybody ever figured out who C and T are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book is NOT ABOUT JACKSON! Aibileen spills a few drops of coffee on Hilly's plate. H looks up to Aibileen slow and deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spilled some, Aibileen. Aibileen takes the cloth from the coffee pitcher handle a dabs the spilled coffee. Aibileen glances at Hilly. A secret burns between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a new plate. One you haven't soiled with a dirty cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen and Minny walk into the church parking lot weari their Sunday best. Minny takes note of all the cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We late? Looks like Bible study done already started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We ain't late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Minny and Aibileen enter the church. Four-hundred memb stand at once. The congregation begins to clap. 128.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny and Aibileen look around trying to figure out the source of adulation. They both start clapping too. Aibileen steps up to a woman in the last pew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who we clappin' for? The woman laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, we clappin' for you. The woman raises a copy of "The Help." Aibileen notices a copy of the book in each member's hand. Aibileen looks to Minny, realizing she's in on it. A REVEREND approaches, hands Aibileen a copy of the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, this is an important time for you and our church. We know you couldn't put your name in here, so we all signed our own. The Reverend then hands her a box wrapped in white paper, tied with a blue ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for the white lady. Tell her we love her like family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter sits between Aibileen and Minny on the sofa thumb through her signed book. Hundreds of signatures cover the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churches over two counties signed our books. All for you and me. Aibileen points to the inside back cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor King signed it, too. He readin' our book. Aibileen glances proudly at the framed portrait of Dr. Ki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did something. We did something good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. Skeeter closes the book and sets it down regretfully. 129.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Skeeter pulls a letter out of her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a job offer from Harper and Row...in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That real good, Miss Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I not taking it. I just wanted to share it with you both. There's no one else I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you mean you not takin' it? This is what you been dreaming of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't leave you two right when things are getting bad from a mess I created. I set out to write a book to make white people thankful. But in the end, what we should say is "sorry."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If bad things happen, they ain't nothing you can do about it. And if they happen, at least now theys a reason behind it. A reason we can wrap our heads around and be proud of... Skeeter nods with little relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I don't mean to rub salt in your wound, but...you ain't got a good life here in Jackson. Plus, your momma's getting better- Minny aggressively chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't got nothing left here but enemies in the Junior League. You done burned ever bridge there is. And you ain't never gone get another man in this town, and ever body know it. So don't walk your white butt to New York, RUN IT! Minny leans over, placing her hand on Skeeter's for the f time since knowing each other. 130.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you listen to me. I'm on take care a Aibileen, and she gone take care a me. Skeeter nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go find your life, Miss Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter stands next to the barn smoking a cigarette readi the Harper and Row offer for the hundredth time. Tires crunch gravel down the drive. Skeeter sees a car moving toward her with the headlights off. Worried, Skeeter looks toward her home. Charlotte can be seen in an upstairs window. Skeeter soon recognizes the car as Hilly's. Hilly parks, lights a cigarette and gets out of her car. Skeeter charges toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Hilly screams and throws her lit cigarette at Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you get an inch closer! Hilly's a mess. Her shirt is half tucked. Her shorts stra to contain a newly developed layer of fat. A horrible fever blister burns hot on Hilly's upper lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've contacted my lawyer, Hibbie Goodman. He's the best libel attorney in Mississippi. You're in big trouble, Missy. And you're going to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't prove anything, Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I one-hundred-percent know you wrote it `cause nobody else in town is as tacky as you. Those nigras of yours are in a lifetime of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly who are you talking about? You don't know anything. 131.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't, do I? You tell Aibileen, the next time she wants to write about my dear friend Elizabeth...uh- huh. Remember her? Had you in her wedding? Let's just say, Aibileen ought to've been a little bit smarter before putting in the L- shaped crack in poor Elizabeth's dining table. And that nigra, Minny? Do I have plans for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, Hilly. Don't give yourself away now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was not me WHO ATE THAT PIE! Hilly storms up the porch steps. Skeeter follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not invite you here! Skeeter yanks Hilly's arm hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to tell your mother what a hippie you've become. She's gonna be disgusted by you. Skeeter can't help but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling my mother on me? Hilly opens the door. Skeeter grabs her. They struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get out of here! Charlotte suddenly appears. Skeeter lets go of Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Hilly...It's been such a long time, Dear. Everything okay, you two? Hilly is shocked by Charlotte's frail appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missus Phelan, I'm...I'm here to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, you're a mess. Are you ill? Hilly self-consciously licks her fever blister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I...I didn't have time to get fixed up before- 132.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, no husband wants to come home and see this. Charlotte peers closely at Hilly's cold sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that...that is horrendous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missus Phelan, I'm here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Hilly. If I didn't know any better, I'd say you've been eating too many...SWEETS? Hilly's face turns purple with embarrassment. Charlotte moves in for the kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact. I'm sure of it. Now GET OUT OF MY HOUSE...before we all get one of those on our lip. Hilly looks back and forth between Skeeter and her mother not knowing what to say. Hilly runs out of the house as Charlotte sashays quietly the living room. Shocked, Skeeter stands alone in the foyer. Hilly sprays gravel across the Phelan yard as she speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Eugenia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Come in here, please. Skeeter gulps as she heads toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte pats the sofa as Skeeter enters and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have plans tomorrow? Bible study? Anything like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ma'am. 133.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. We're going shopping. Skeeter lets out a big sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Cause no single daughter of mine is going to New York, representing the great state of Mississippi, without a proper cosmopolitan wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very proud of you, Eugenia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know about New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend of Constantine's told me. Charlotte reaches down and pulls up her copy of "The Help

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you do me the honor of signing my copy? Skeeter nods. Charlotte hands Skeeter a pen. Her hand trembles as she signs the book, never having guessed how it would feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen washes dishes as the phone begins to ring. She answers. Minny screams on the other end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny stands barefoot inside a phone booth, her lip swoll face bleeding. Her kids stand outside, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fired Leroy last night! And when Leroy ask why, his boss say Mister Holbrook told him to do it. Said his nigger wife the reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Law!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He try to kill me with he bare hands! He threw the kids in the yard, lock me in the bathroom, and say he gone set the house on fire. 134.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you now?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas station. I climbed out the window, and we all ran here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on come there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Aibileen...I'm pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny, now, you listen to me. That baby gone be fine, and you ain't never gone lose your job. Mister Johnny told you that hisself. They's more book money coming. Your baby ain't gone know about gettin' beat. You hear me? You free, Minny! You are free. Minny lets out a chuckle of relief and wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you... The Leefolt front door opens. Elizabeth calls out.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Aibileen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen enters to find Elizabeth and Hilly staring at he Elizabeth is two weeks WAY PAST DUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. Hilly licks her cold sore as she steps forward. She glide her hand across the L-shaped crack in the Elizabeth's tab drawing Aibileen's attention to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen, the silver I lent Elizabeth last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It not polished good? Humidity been fighting me on polishing day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you returned it, three pieces were missing out of the felt wrapper. A fork and two spoons. 135.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme...lemme go look in the kitchen, maybe I left some behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know as well as I do that silver's not in the kitchen. Aibileen turns to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You check in Mae Mobley's bed? She been putting things-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear her, Elizabeth? She's trying to blame it on a toddler. Elizabeth won't look at Aibileen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't stole no silver. Elizabeth whispers to Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she doesn't have them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it behooves me to inform you that you are fired, Aibileen. And I'll be calling the police. They know me. Mae Mobley enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibee, my froat hurts. Mae Mobley coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go get her some syrup, Miss Leefolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth can take care of her child. Elizabeth looks to Hilly, appearing somewhat upset with t suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go get the couch syrup. Hilly glares at Aibileen as Elizabeth runs down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't tolerate liars! Mae Mobley becomes scared and hides behind Aibileen's leg 136.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't steal no silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about silver. I'm talking about those things you wrote about Elizabeth. Maybe I can't send you to jail for what you wrote, but I can send you to jail for being a thief. And your friend, Minny? That nigra's got a nice surprise coming to her. Johnny Foote listens to what I say. She's as good as- Aibileen shouts, interrupting Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman!...I know something about you. Don't you forget that. Hilly narrows her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what Yule May says, they's a lot a time to write letters from jail. Plenty a time to write ever person in Jackson the truth about you, and the paper is free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody would believe something you wrote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Already sold a lot a books. Fear floods into Hilly's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go, Aibiee! Aibileen kneels down as Elizabeth returns with the syrup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, you need to get back to bed. You got a fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooo! Don't go, Aibee. Please don't leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gots to, Baby. I am so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Are you going to take care of another little girl? 137.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Baby, that's not the reason. I don't want to leave you, but...It's time for me to retire. You my last little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby Girl, I need you to remember ever thing I told you. Okay? Do you remember what I told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To wipe my bottom good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Baby. The other. What you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You is kind. You is smart. You is important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Baby Girl. Aibileen squeezes Mae Mobley for the last time. They both cry together. Hilly speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to go now, Aibileen! Aibileen rises up from Mae Mobley and turns to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give my sweet girl a chance. Elizabeth avoids eye contact. Aibileen turns and walks aw As Elizabeth leans down to pick up Mae Mobley....HER WATE BREAKS. She glares at Hilly with shock and regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen steps out of the house with her purse. She walks stoically down the driveway. Tears stream down face. Mae Mobley runs to the living room window crying. She bea on the glass from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibeeeee! Don't go! Aibileen never turns. 138.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mae Mobley was my last baby. In just thirty minutes, I felt like my whole life was done. Of the thirteen maids, seven of us got fired. Several other maids got fired who had nothin' to do with our book. Guess our stories weren't so unique after all...But, like Minny, we was all free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly, even fatter now, sifts through the day's mail.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And we's was a lot freer than Hilly Holbrook. She comes across a piece from Celia Foote addressed to Th Starving Children of Africa Fund. A smug smile forms. She opens the envelope to find a check for $200.00 made o to: TWO-SLICE HILLY! Hilly screams as she rips the check into pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minny folds laundry on a picnic table.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ever so often, we all get a nice piece of book money in the mail. `Manna from heaven' we like to call it. Minny looks across the table and smiles at Celia who is holding and playing with Minny's newborn child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on tombstone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Born December 24th 1883 Died March 15th, 1963 A bouquet of flowers lay at the foot of the tombstone. A copy of "The Help" leans against it. In the distance, a cab slowly pulls away with Skeeter ins 139.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aibileen sits at her kitchen table, typing on Skeeter's o typewriter. We watch as keys write out the rest of Aibileen's voice over.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thousands of our books went out all over the world. We had got paid to tell the truth and we just couldn't believe it... Aibileen takes this last page out of the typewriter and places it behind two hundred other typed out pages. She looks up to the framed picture of Treelore and rises the table with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter smiles as she reads from a book in her corner off The Manhattan skyline rises behind her. She wears Pucci. Her hair is perfectly styled. She looks gorgeous. She sets the book down on her desk and picks up the phone The book's cover reads: "All My Babies" By Aibileen Clark Next to the book is a glass box. Constantine's corn pipe rests inside.

dialogues.speaker: AIBILEEN'S NEW HOME
dialogues.text: Aibileen, 70, rises from a sofa. Her hair is gray. Readin glasses hang on a chain from around her neck. As she begins a slow walk down the hall, we see the surroundings of her new home for the first time. It's muc bigger, well furnished and beautiful. She passes a study lined with shelves of books. A copy of "The Help" and "All My Babies" are placed side by side. At the end of the hall, Aibileen approaches the opened do of a brightly lit, sparkling white, bathroom. She enters the bathroom and closes the door.
